  • The role of FNR II in the control of yﬁD expression It is clear that enhanced yﬁD expression in HlyX-expres-sing cultures is not due to the superior ability of HlyX ( compared with FNR ) to activate transcription from Class I promoters but rather that HlyX occupation of FNR II has a neutral/positive effect on yﬁD expression , whereas FNR has a negative effect at this site . [9767578]
  • The ability of FNR , located in a typical class II position , to only weakly activate expression of yhjA in the absence of OxyR suggests that the role of OxyR might be to counteract the effects of an as-yet-unidentiﬁed regulator that inhibits the action of FNR . [17464064]
  • The effect of the fnr mutation may well be indirect in this case , since FNR probably controls the expression of genes that are involved in the reduction of nitrite to NO . [17449618]

  • Anaerobic ndh expression is repressed by FNR but enhanced in fnr mutants during anaerobic-growth in rich medium ( Spiroet al. , 1989 ; Green & Guest , 1994 ) . [9308170]
  • During anaerobic-growth , transcription of the hmp gene is repressed by FNR , but severe exposure to NO stress results in inactivation of FNR and hence de-repression of hmp expression [ 18 ] . [16417494]
  • FNR primarily functions to regulate anaerobic metabolism in E. coli and other bacteria by co-ordinating changes in gene expression that optimize growth potential in different niches . [20522491]
  • The Arc-activated cydAB ( 1 ) , and Arc-repressed sodA ( 13 ) and lpdA ( 26 ) , are also under the direct negative control of FNR , a regulator that co-mediates gene expression in response to the redox conditions of growth ( 38 ) . [14711822]

  • Introduction The expression of genes required for anaerobic-growth of Escherichia coli is tightly controlled , and many such genes are reguiated by the FNR protein , a transcription factor that is activated by the absence of oxygen in the medium ( reviewed by Spiro and Guest , 1990 ) . [8437517]
  • The transcriptional-regulator FNR of E. coli controls the expression of many genes required for anaerobic metabo-lism in response to O2 . [8588737]
  • The expression of anaerobic respiration and of related functions of E. coli is controlled by the positive gene regulator FNR , which activates transcription in the absence of 02 . [1854188]
  • The direct oxygen sensor FNR activates ` anaerobic ' gene expression in the absence of oxygen [ 31,32 ] . [22870390]
  • The FNR protein is required for anaerobic expression , while the NARL protein mediates nitrate induction . [1629153]
  • The resuits in Tabie 7 confirm that expression from pnrf was totally FNR dependent and induced during anaerobic-growth . [7854119]
  • The requirement of CRP and FNR for anaerobic clyA expression was subsequently investigated . [11053378]
  • The reason why residual twofold anaerobic induction of , B-galactosidase activity is observed in a fir mutant is unclear , but we can not rule out the possibility that ArcA has some influence on anaerobic expression in the absence of a functional FNR protein when the region of DNA including promoter 7 is present on this construct . [1592804]
  • The novel nature of fdhF gene expression has further been emphasized by the fact that anaerobic induction is independent of the FNR protein ( Birkmann ef al. , 1987b ) and transcription from the promoter is dependent upon the presence of a functional NtrA protein ( synonyms GInF , RpoN , ( T̂ ' * ) -LCB- Birkmann etal . [2181234]
  • Moreover , they suggest that FNR-dependent activation of hyp expression is completely dependent on the downstream half-site , and that both FNR half-sites are required for maximum an-aerobic induction . [14612240]
  • As predicted , exchanging the FNR sites so that activation depended on a low-affinity site and repression on a high-affinity site caused repression of yfiD : : lac expression both anaerobically and microaerobically ( Table 3 ) . [11169114]
  • Aerobically , FNR is largely inactive , neither FNR site is occupied and yfiD expression is low . [11932447]
  • Microaerobically , a low level of active FNR appears in the bacteria , and the high afinity activating FNR site ( FNR I ) becomes occupied , allowing yﬁD expression . [11932447]
  • Microaerobically , active FNR begins to appear in the bacterial cytoplasm and the high afﬁnity activating FNR site ( FNR I ) becomes occupied , allowing yfiD expression . [11932447]
  • Under these conditions there is insuficient active FNR to occupy the low afinity upstream repressing FNR site ( FNR II ) , and the data presented here suggests that ArcA binding to this region ensures that this is so , thereby facilitating maximal yﬁD expression . [11932447]
  • Therefore , the enhanced expression of yfiD under microaerobic conditions is dependent on the presence of a high-affinity activating FNR site ( 240.5 ) and a lower affinity repressing FNR site ( 293.5 ) . [11169114]
  • The expression of dcuC * 9-9lacZ was increased by a factor of about 2.2 compared to that in the wild type , but the responses to oxygen , nitrate , and the regulators FNR , NarL , and NarP were comparable to those in the wild type ( data not shown ) . [10368146]
  • Effect of Arc and FNR on moeA-lacZ expression Although nitrate increased the level of moe-lacZ expression , oxygen had a negative effect on moe expression . [11357510]
  • FNR-independent expression is minimal , and the simplest explanation for the results is that NarL interacts with FNR : we suppose that the G85A change in FNR alters the conformation ol FNR to interfere with this interaction . [8437517]

  • It is of interest that whereas the dependence of 'D [ glpAJ ( Oxr ) - lac ] expression on FNR was decreased , the dependence on CAP appears to be increased . [2403539]

  • Here it has been shown that the anaerobic transcription factor FNR is the major activator of yﬁD expression , but that the extent of FNR-mediated activation can be modulated by the indirect oxygen sensor ArcA and the pyruvate sensor PdhR . [11932447]
  • These results indicate that the anaerobic repression of dctA is mediated primarily by ArcA , with a minor contribution from FNR that is likely to be related to the activation of arcA expression by FNR ( 6 ) . [10482502]

  • Previous transcriptional fusion studies have reported a 3-fold increase in the expression level of this gene during aerobic-growth , and this decreased expression during anaerobiosis is independent of FNR , as well as ArcA ( 38 ) . [12754220]
  • Gene expression suggests that ArcA is active in aerobic ECOM4LA , while FNR is not . [20709841]
  • Many of these catabolic pathways are controlled in response to the availability of oxygen and alternative electron acceptors at the level of gene expression Moreover , many of the metabolic transitions between aerobic and anaerobic states are controlled at the transcription level , primarily by the activities of two anaerobically activated gene regulatory systems composed of FNR and ArcA/B ( 26 ) . [20075074]
  • Mean gene expression data ( fold change ) , acquired from the WT and ECOM4LA strains grown in triplicate , for all genes that are known to be regulated by the anaerobic regulator FNR or ArcA according to RegulonDB were compared to the reported function of the regulator ( activator or repressor ) . [20709841]
  • Hence , the membrane-bound sensor of respiratory activity and anaerobic metabolism ArcB [ 28 -- 30 ] mediates changes in gene expression through its cognate regulator ArcA when the supply of oxygen is insufficient to fully penetrate the cytoplasm and inactivate the direct oxygen sensor FNR [ 31,32 ] . [22870390]

[10482502]

[11932447]

FNR acts as the major regulator of anaerobic metabolism and ArcA as the regulator of aerobic metabolism . [9230919]
  • TorC autoregulation is different from tor anaerobic control The torCAD operon is fully induced in anaerobiosis but , in contrast to all other known anaerobic respiratory systems , this control is mediated neither by FNR , a pleiotropic anae-robic regulator , nor by ArcA , a response-regulator involved in redox control of numerous genes ( Simon et al. , 1994 ) . [10411745]
  • Abbreviations used : ArcA , anaerobic respiratory control ; FNR , fumarate and nitrate reductase regulator ; HMP , ﬂavohaemoglobin ; TMAO , trimethylamine N-oxide . [16417494]
  • Remarkably , anaerobic control is mediated neither by FNR , the general anaerobic regulator , nor by ArcA , another anaerobic global regulator ( luchi and Lin , 1988 ; Pascal et aL , 1984 ) . [8596446]
  • Thus , under aerobic conditions , an increase in the Fe-S cluster demand via overexpression of FNR relieves repression of the isc operon , presumably due to the competition between FNR and IscR for acquiring Fe-S clusters from the Isc machinery . [23075318]

  • The likely explanation for this is that most of the genes controlled by these promoters encode products that play a role in anaerobic respiration of nitrate and nitrite , and thus their expression is fully induced only in both the absence of oxygen ( signalled via FNR ) and the presence of nitrate or nitrite ( signalled by NarL ) [ 4,29,30 ] . [19245365]
  • The genes for fumarate respiration and related enzymes ( dcuB , frdABCD , fumB , ttdAB , and ttdT ) are subject to anaerobic induction by the oxygen sensor FNR and to nitrate repression by the NarX-NarL two-component system ( 15 , 16 , 37 , 46 ) . [20233924]
  • Discussion The ndh gene is an unusual member of the FNR reguion because it is repressed rather than being activated under anaerobic conditions , and KMnO4 footprinting studies have now shown that RNA polymerase can not form an open complex at the ndh promoter in the presence of FNR . [8065261]
  • The results show that the dcuB gene is expressed exclusively under anaerobic conditions in a manner that is FNR dependent and that it is repressed by NarL in the presence of nitrate and is subject to CRP-mediated catabolite repression . [9852003]
  • The dcuB gene is expressed exclusively under anaerobic conditions in a manner that is largely FNR dependent , is repressed by nitrate through a mechanism that is mostly NarL mediated , and is strongly induced by C4-dicar-boxylates anaerobically . [9852003]
  • Maximal expression of PnarG occurs under anaerobic-growth conditions in the presence of nitrate and , in addition to FNR , requires the DNA-binding proteins NarL and IHF , which bind to DNA sequences located upstream of the FNR site ( Rabin et al. , 1992 ; Schroder et al. , 1993 ) ( Fig. 1B ) . [11115116]
  • Transcript-profiling experiments have shown that the abundance of the ydhY and downstream transcripts is enhanced under anaerobic conditions in the presence of FNR ( Constantinidou et al. , 2006 ; Kang et al. , 2005 ) , and that the transcripts are less abundant in the presence of nitrate ( Constantinidou et al. , 2006 ) . [18227264]
  • Thirteen of these operons were also identified in the study of Kang et al. ( 2 ) , but anaerobic-growth in the presence of nitrate or nitrite was essential for revealing the FNR depend-ence of most of the remaining operons . [16377617]
  • However , repression in the presence of oxygen or nitrate was signiﬁcantly reduced with respect to the monocopy fusion , which suggests that an increase in the copy number of caiF renders transcription of the gene less dependent on the anaerobic regulators FNR and NarL . [8631699]
  • Other targets for future research Synthesis of three further proteins is strongly up-regu-lated by nitrate-activated NarL during anaerobic-growth in the presence of nitrate but is not dependent on activation by the FNR protein . [22029434]
  • As NarG is a major catalyst for the formation of NO in the cytoplasm , protection mechanisms become essential when NarL and FNR are both active , which is during anaerobic-growth in the presence of a high concentration of nitrate . [22029434]
  • FNR repression was often most apparent during anaerobic-growth in the presence of nitrite . [16377617]
  • Activity of this promoter is totaiiy dependent on FNR and partialiy dependent on NarL : expression is induced by anaerobic-growth conditions but optimai activity depends on the inciusion of nitrite or nitrate in the growth medium ( Griffiths and Coie , 1987 ; Page et ai , 1990 ) . [8437517]
  • A mutation in FNR that affects induction o/pnirB Since expression from pnirB is dependent on FNR in all growth conditions , it is possible that additional proteins , responsible for nitrite and nitrate induction , exert their effect by interacting with FNR . [8437517]
  • Transcripts that are less abundant ( repressed ) in the reference pool relative to the test sample include those that are induced directly or indirectly during aerobic-growth , transcripts that are induced during anaerobic-growth by nitrate or nitrite , or repressed by FNR . [16377617]
  • Conversely , transcripts that are more abundant in the reference pool than in the test sample include genes that , directly or indirectly , are activated by FNR or induced during anaerobic-growth . [16377617]
  • Microarray data supplemented with bioinformatic data revealed that the FNR ( fumarate and nitrate reductase regulator ) regulon includes at least 104 , and possibly as many as 115 , operons , 68 of which are activated and 36 are repressed during anaerobic-growth . [16417494]
  • The ynfEFGHI operon is induced under anaerobic conditions in a fumarate nitrate reduction regulator ( FNR ) - dependent manner ( 40 ) . [23913318]
  • Under anaerobic conditions ndh is repressed by the regulator of fumarate and nitrate reduction ( FNR ) . [9308170]
  • Under anaerobic conditions , the expression of ndh is repressed by FNR ( regulator of fumarate and nitrate reduction ) ( 13 , 20 , 21 ) , while the expression of cyoABCDE is repressed by FNR under anaerobic-growth conditions ( 6 ) . [17513468]
  • Under microaerobic conditions , the pyruvate dehydrogenase complex is rapidly inactivated by the increasing NADH/NAD + ratio ( 10 ) ; rapid transcriptional and posttranslational activation of the PFL system would result in an efficient shift to anaerobic metab-olism , and under these conditions , FNR is probably the principle activator of pfl transcription . [1592804]
  • In this study , we found that , although both FNR-AR1 and FNR-AR3 are necessary for transcription activation of PnarG and PdmsA under conditions in which FNR is the only known activator , the requirements for FNR-AR1 and FNR-AR3 are changed in the presence of additional activators at PnarG . [11115116]
  • Under conditions in which all these factors are functional , we found that the contributions of FNR-AR1 and FNR-AR3 to transcription activation were greatly reduced compared with when FNR functioned alone . [11115116]
  • Although FNRD154A is able to activate gene transcription under aerobic conditions , it does not exist exclusively as dimeric form under this condition and the ratio between dimer and monomer varies under different conditions and concentrations , rendering difﬁculties to characterize the binding of FNR to its regulated promoters [ 9 ] . [22326866]
  • Using reverse-transcription polymerase chain reaction we show that although the flavorubredoxin gene ( flrd ) is transcribed in both aerobic and anaerobic conditions , anaerobiosis induced transcription up to 12-fold , under fermentative conditions ; a 28-fold stimulation was observed in an E. coli fnr mutant strain , showing that the flavorubredoxin gene is negatively regulated by FNR . [12586421]
  • The FNRsystem The product of the fnr gene ( FNR ) is now known to be involved in the anaerobic activation or repression of a variety of enzymes , and it may also repress its own transcription under anaerobic conditions ( Fig. 3 ) 6 . [1957353]
  • The proposed interaction of FNR , the product of the fnr gene , and RNA polymer-ase ( RNP ) under conditions in which frd transcription is induced or not induced is shown . [3298218]
  • This operon is therefore another candidate for encoding proteins that protect E. coli against RNS , especially in anaerobic environments where FNR might be inactivated by severe NO damage ( 11 , 12 , 18 ) . [17449618]
  • Such is the case for complex II in E. coli , with the complex II bio-synthetic operon ( sdhCDAB ) being negatively regulated by ArcAB and FNR in response to oxygen conditions ( i.e. anaerobic ) and positively regulated by CRP in the absence of glucose [ 108 -- 110 ] . [22985599]
  • FNR is known to induce the transcription of the E. coli nrfABCDEFG operon during anaerobic cell growth [ 22 ] , and to negatively regulate the transcription of E. coli hmp [ 7 ] . [12586421]
  • Expression of yﬁD in E. coli is known to be controlled by the transcription regulator FNR ( 7 , 8 ) and in response to pH-stress conditions ( 9 , 10 ) . [11444864]
  • In E. coli , the NO-induction of the hmpA gene was reported to be dependent on MetR , a transcriptional-regulator of the methionine biosynthetic pathway , under aerobic conditions ( 23 ) and on FNR , an oxygen-responsive regulator , under anaerobic conditions ( 24 ) . [14718666]
  • In Escherichia coli , the shift between aerobic and anaerobic metabolism , which is controlled primarily by the global transcriptional-regulator FNR ( 13 , 23 , 32 ) , is known to involve the repression and activation of hundreds of genes ( 25 ) . [15547274]
  • In the Gram negative bacterium Escherichia coli , this process is primarily controlled by the global transcription regulator FNR ( fumarate and nitrate reduction ) which is activated under anaerobic conditions and upon activation , regulates the expression of more than one hundred genes in E. coli genome [ 1,2 ] . [22326866]
  • In the absence of oxygen , FNR binds to promoters of the genes of anaerobic metabolism and activates transcription . [8871401]
  • As synthesis of both of these nitrite reductases is dependent on transcription activation by the FNR protein , they are active only during anaerobic-growth and fulfil a dissimilatory rather than an assimilatory role ( Cole , 1978 ) . [1435259]
  • This induction is dependent on the regulatory protein , FNR , a factor essential for the transcription of a number of genes expressed during anaerobic-growth ( Cole and Ward , 1973 ; Lambden and Guest , 1976 ; Griffiths and Cole , 1987 ) . [2845227]
  • Finally , under anaerobic conditions in the presence of FNR , active FNR bound at the -50.5 and -94.5 sites will prevent RNA polymerase contacting the - 58 to - 1 3 2 region and this , presumably accompanied by negatively acting contacts between the bound FNR and RNA poiymerase , results in the FNR-dependent repression of ndh transcription , as illustrated in Fig. 8C . [8065261]

  • Furthermore , the anaerobic transcription of fnrS was abolished in a fnr strain , thus demonstrating that the global regulatory protein FNR induces FnrS transcription in response to anoxic growth conditions . [20075074]
  • Under aerobic-growth conditions , proteolysis decreases FNR protein levels ( 12 , 38 ) , while under anaerobic conditions , FNR represses its own transcription ( 24 , 41 , 44 , 47 , 54 ) . [17293415]
  • A previous study indicated that FNR present in aerobic cells can be activated upon a shift to anaerobic conditions in the presence of a protein synthesis inhibitor ( 8 ) . [15547274]
  • Transport studies suggest that the Dcu systems are expressed exclusively under an-aerobic conditions , activated by the anaerobic activator protein FNR , and repressed in the presence of nitrate . [9852003]

  • It has long been appreciated that the activity of FNR must be regulated by O2 availability , since FNR dependent gene expression is observed in vivo only under anaerobic conditions , while similar levels of this protein are present in both aerobic and anaerobic grown cells . [9990723]

  • Under anaerobic conditions it is likely that the opposing activities of FNR ( - ) and Arr ( + ) compete in order to ` fine-tune ' ndh expression . [8809757]
  • Thus , under some anaerobic-growth conditions Arr may compete with FNR and IHF for occupation of the ndh promoter and , by acting positively , Arr may counteract the negative effects of FNR and IHF to ` finetune ' ndh expression . [9308170]

  • FNR activates transcription of many genes in response to anaerobic conditions . [16417494]
  • FNR acts as a dual transcription regulator that activates certain genes required for anaerobic-growth and represses many genes required for aerobic-growth [ 22 ] . [22152010]
  • FNR activates transcription of a number of genes coding for enzymes required under anaerobic-growth conditions and represses transcription of some genes for aerobic functions ( 11 , 20 ) . [12923108]
  • Although much progress has been achieved in understanding what limits FNR function to anaerobic-growth conditions ( Kiley and Beinert , 1999 ) , the mechanism by which FNR regulates transcription initiation of its target genes is not as well understood . [11115116]
  • FNR is selectively active as a transcription factor under anaerobic-growth conditions , where it has been shown to control the transcription of hundreds of genes , many of which are necessary for adaptation to O2-limiting growth conditions ( 10 , 16 , 25 , 46 ) . [17293415]
  • In vivo transcription studies using promoter fusions with 59 deletions conﬁrmed that both FNR sites are required for maximum repression under anaerobic conditions . [14766919]

  • FNR and IHF acted as weak repressors under anaerobic conditions . [7565112]
  • FNR and NifA act as positive regulators under anaerobic conditions . [1854188]
  • When the terminal electron acceptor , O2 , is no longer available , FNR represses the synthesis of enzymes involved in aerobic respiration and increases the synth-esis of enzymes required for anaerobic respiration . [11115116]
  • The active ( anaerobic ) and inactive ( aerobic ) forms of FNR are readily interconverted in vivo depending on oxygen and iron availability ( Engel et at . [8497198]
  • The inactive form from aerobically growing cells is converted reversibly to the active ( anaerobic ) FNR in the absence of O2 and vice versa ( Engel et al. 1991 ) . [8588737]
  • In response to O2 availability , FNR is converted reversibly from the aerobic ( inactive ) state to the anaerobic ( active ) state . [8588737]
  • Therefore , it is assumed that by the alkylation assay two functionally different forms of FNR are recognized , an aerobic , or metal depleted , inactive form and an anaerobic active form . [1854188]
  • Anoxic conditions FNR → FNR inactive ← active Oxic conditions In vivo , FNR can be inactivated not only by O2 , but also by a positive redox potential ( Unden et al. 1990 ) . [8588737]
  • As shown below , the properties of O2 diffusion to the cytoplasm are consistent with the presence of O2 in the cytoplasm under aerobic and microaerobic conditions , which is a prerequisite for direct interaction between FNR and O2 ( Becker et al. , 1996 ; Unden et al. , 1997 ; Tseng et al. , 1996 ) . [11931557]
  • Overexpression and puriﬁcation of FNR protein , containing the DA154 substitution , which renders FNR active under aerobic conditions , was as described in Wing et al. ( 2000 ) . [15978080]
  • Mutants of this type produce FNR protein that is partially active also under oxic conditions ( Kiley and Reznikoff 1991 ; Lazazzera et al. 1993 ) . [8588737]
  • This can be concluded from the fact that iron limitation of the cells is not obligatory for the switch and that Fe availability under physiological conditions is not related to the functional state of FNR ( Niehaus et al. 1991 ) . [8588737]
  • Therefore FNR function has to be controlled by changes in the functional state , and it has been shown that inactive FNR from aerobically grown E. coli can be converted under anaerobic conditions in vivo to the functional state without the need for protein synthesis ( Engel et al. , 1991 ) . [11931557]

[16677314]
  • During aerobic-growth , transcription from the nir and nrf promoters is repressed , but expression is induced during anaerobiosis due to activation by the anaerobically regulated transcription factor FNR ( Jayaraman et al. 1989 ; Bell et al. 1990 ; Page et al. 1990 ) . [9382703]
  • FNR has been known to respond to th intracellular [ Fe / Fe ] ratio under strictly anaerobic 2 + 3 + condition , whereas Arc system has more signiﬁcant effect on the cell growth in microaerobic condition ( Drapal and Sawers , 1995 ; Gunsalus , 1992 ; Iuchi et al. , 1990 ) . [15781419]
  • Strains unable to synthesize the global transcriptional-regulator FNR ( Guest et al. , 1996 ) were also defective in the synthesis of both hydrogenase isoenzymes ( Sawers et al. , 1985 ) , strongly suggesting that FNR was responsible for anaerobic induction of enzyme synthesis . [10537212]
  • Introduction The anaerobic respiratory systems of tschenchia coii are only expressed under anaerobtc conditions - The anaerobic dercpression of the corresponding genes is mediated by the FNR protein , which ts thought to function as an anaerobic transcriptional-activator ( Lambden and Guest , 1976 , Newman and Colo , 1978 : Chippaux et al. , 1978 ; Shaw ef al. . [2181237]
  • The mod operon is transcribed under both oxic and anoxic conditions and does no appear to be subject to control by FNR protein or Arc proteins , global regulators of anaerobic respiratory pathways ( Lynch and Lin 1996a ; Rosentel et al. 1995 ; Spiro and Guest 1990 ) . [11357510]
  • The promoter , which has an FNR box in its vicinity , is activated some 20-fold by anaerobic-growth ( Fig. 2 ; Arai et al. 1991 ) . [7747934]
  • The uncertainty arises because hmp expression is repressed by FNR , and this repression is relieved during anaerobic-growth under conditions of severe nitrosative stress ( Table 1 ; Cruz-Ramos et al. , 2002 ; Corker & Poole , 2003 ; Pullan et al. , 2007 ) . [22029434]
  • The repression of ndhll by FNR occurs only under anaerobic conditions ( Spiro et al. 1989 ) . [1854188]
  • FNR shows no homology to regulators of two-component-regulatory systems and no phosphorylation , neither under aerobic nor anaerobic conditions , could be demonstrated ( Green et al. 1991 ) . [1854188]
  • Other factors , such as ArcAB ( regulator of anaerobic and aerobic metabolism inhibiting the Krebs cycle , the electron transport chain and PDH activity in anaerobic conditions ) , activate the PFL enzyme ( De Graef et al. , 1999 ) , which is also regulated by FNR . [14595781]
  • We supposed that FNR was responsible for the effect in the anaerobic condition , because FNR was the global transcriptional-regulator that controlled gene expression in response to the transition between aerobic and anaerobic-growth ( Green et al. , 2001 ) . [17618229]
  • During preparation of this paper , Salmon et al. ( 73 ) reported results of global gene expression proﬁles of E. coli K-12 strain MC4100 grown under aerobic and anaerobic conditions and the effect of FNR on these global gene expression patterns . [15659690]
  • Thus , expression of ttdA requires transcriptional activation by FNR , which is in the active state only under anaerobic conditions ( Guest et al. , 1996 ) . [19661178]
  • CHR activity was always high because the cai operon ( responsible for the expression of carnitine metabolism ) was controlled by protein regulators such as FNR ( transcriptional-regulator under anaerobic conditions ) , catabolic repression via protein receptor ( CRP ) of AMPc , histones ( H-NS ) , and the transcriptional factor j 2 ( RpoS ) , which is expressed when the cell reaches the stationary phase of growth and inhibits carnitine metabolism ( Eichler et al. , 1996 ) . [14595781]

  • Expression of a caiF-lacZ operon fusion was subject to FNR regulator-mediated anaerobic induction and cyclic AMP receptor protein activation . [8631699]
  • receptor protein ( CRP ) or catabolite gene activator protein ( CAP ) of E. coil , and the homology suggested that FNR performs a role in anaerobic gene activation analogous to that of CRP in catabolite gene activation . [1957353]

  • A mutation in the fnr gene , however , only reduces anaerobic induction fivefold , indicating that FNR is not the only factor involved in the anaerobic activation process ( Sawers and Bock , J. Bacteriol . [1592804]
  • Here , we report an anaerobic regulatory mechanism of hmp induction directly mediated by NO , involving nitrosylation of the [ 4Fe ± 4S ] 2 + clusters in the FNR protein . [12093725]
  • The FNR protein that regulates transitions between aerobic and anaerobic-growth is inactivated as a consequence of nitrosative damage , but we challenge the idea that FNR is a physiologically relevant sensor of NO , except under the most severe nitrosative stress . [22029434]
  • The EtrA protein is functionally as well as structurally similar to FNR , given that its major role appears to be in the regulation of anaerobic respiration . [7747934]
  • Further studies with acn-lac2 gene fusions and a wider range of transcription regulators indicated that acnA expression is initiated by G ~ ~ from PIacnAa , nd from PZacnA it is activated directly or indirectly by CRP , FruR , Fur and SoxRS , and repressed by ArcA and FNR . [9421904]
  • This showed that the acnB gene is subject to repression by ArcA , Fis and FruR and activation by CRP , whereas the a c n A gene is repressed by ArcA and FNR , activated by FruR , CRP , Fur and SoxRS , and initiated by a38in stationary phase . [9421904]
  • Both genes are subject to ArcA-mediated anaerobicrepression and CRP-mediated catabolite repression , but they differ insofar as a c n A gene transcription is activated by Fur , SoxRS and FruR , can be initiated by t ~ a ~ d ~ is r , epressed by FNR , whereas the acnB gene is repressed by Fis and FruR but unaffected by the other regulators . [9421904, 9421904]
  • Expressionfrom the suc promoter was repressed by IHF and partially activated by d8but it was not regulated by ArcA , FNR , CRP , FruR or Fis , and not repressed by glucose or anaerobiosis , indicating that the well-established catabolite and anaerobic repression of ODH synthesis is imposed elsewhere . [9720032]
  • Incontrast , the / pel promoter was repressed by both glucose ( via a CRP-independentmechanism ) and anaerobiosis ( mediated by ArcA ) , and activated by Fis , but it was not regulated by FNR , FruR , IHF or These observations support the view that transcription of the sucABCD genes is primarily initiated and regulated at the upstream sdh promoter , and that the Ipd promoter is independently co-regulated with Pdh ( primarily by ArcAmediated repression ) rather than with PsucDirect evidence for co-transcription of the entire sdhCDAksucABCD region from PHNw t as obtained by detecting a 10 kb transcript inm c and me mutants , but not inthe parental strains .   • In contrast , inactivation of the fnr gene had no significant effect on expression of the ZpdA-lac2 fusion , but expression was repressed by the multicopy fnr + plasmid , suggesting that excess FNR can either invade the promoter and impair transcription or alternatively function indirectly by activating ArcA synthesis ( Compan & Touati , 1994 ) . [9720032]
  • It is now apparent from studies with the corresponding l a c 2 fusions that the fumA promoter resembles PacnBin being anaerobically repressed by ArcA , whereas the fumC promoter resembles P2acnAin its dual regulation by ArcA and FNR , although there is evidence that fumC transcription is partially facilitated by readthrough from the upstream fumA gene promoter ( Woods & Guest , 1987 ; Guest & Russell , 1992 ; Gruer & Guest , 1994 ; Park & Gunsalus , 1995 ) . [9421904]

  • Thus , ArcA and FNR regulate respiration in response to oxygen availability ( the variable in these experiments ) , CRP and Lrp sense nutritional state via cAMP and L-leucine concentrations , and Fis , H-NS and IHF modify DNA topology , which is itself dependent on energy status [ 7,25 -- 27 ] . [22870390]
  • Thus , it is concluded that ArcA , CRP , Fis , FNR , H-NS , IHF and Lrp are truly global regulators , at least as far as the response to oxygen availability is concerned , in the sense that their outputs create the transcriptional framework upon which local regulators operate in response to specific unstable environments Table 1 . [22870390]
  • The influence of CRP on the transcriptome progressively increased with increased aerobiosis , whereas the activities of ArcA , FNR , IHF and Lrp decreased as aerobiosis increased . [22870390]
  • Many of the transcriptional changes observed were brought about by global TFs such as ArcA , FNR , CRP , IHF , pdhR and fur in ATPase and NOX ( Fig. 4 ) . [20299454]
  • By these criteria , ArcA , CRP , Fis , FNR , H-NS , IHF and Lrp were designated as global TFs in E. coli K-12 [ 24 ] . [22870390]
  • Transcription of the glp operons is subject to multiple controls , including catabolite repression mediated by cyclic AMP-CRP and respiratory control mediated by the FNR and ArcA/ArcB systems ( 19 , 28 ) . [8955387]
  • In contrast , strong responses to anaerobiosis and glucose ( a source of pyruvate ) mediated by global regulators ( ArcA , FNR and CRP ) are likely to be less beneficial . [8057842]
  • For ArcA and FNR , the cultures were grown anaerobically to A650 = 0.4 in L broth + glucose ( 11 mfui ) , and for CRP , cultures were grown aerobically to ASM = 0.8 In L broth . [8057842]
  • This situation exactly parallels that of fumarate reductase and succinate dehydrogenase , in which the corresponding frdABCD and sdhCDAB operons are subject to the same differential regulation by FNR in one case and the cyclic AMP-CRP complex plus the anaerobic repressor in the other , and the enzyme complexes are specifically adapted to accept electrons from menaquinione in fumarate respiration ( fumarate reductase ) or to donate electrons to ubiquinone in aerobic respiration ( succinate dehydrogenase ) ( 11 , 17 , 24 , 35 ) . [2656658]
  • Transcriptional monocopy lacZ fusion studies showed that both operons are coexpressed during anaerobic-growth in the presence of carnitine , respond to common environmental stimuli ( like glucose and nitrate ) , and are modulated positively by the same general regulators , CRP and FNR , and negatively by H-NS . [9573142]
  • Like cai and ﬁx operons , the caiF gene appeared to be positively controlled by CRP and FNR and negatively controlled by H-NS and the NarL ( plus nitrate ) regulator . [9573142]
  • We thank C. Park , B. Wanner , D. LaPorte , S. Maloy , J. Cronan , Jr. , R. W. Simons , and H. Aiba for strains ; R. W. Simons for plasmids and phage ; H. Wing for puriﬁed FNR DA154 ; N. J.   • Furthermore , no effect of CRP was found in vivo by either mutation of the CRP binding site or use of strains that lacked CRP ( data not shown ) , indicating that under the conditions tested , CRP does not regulate the FNR promoter . [17293415]
  • Thus , these data suggest that under such conditions , FNR and CRP are in competition for binding at PhlyE , and that the simplest explanation of these observations is that FNR is more efﬁciently bound than CRP at PhlyE but is not as effective as CRP in activating hlyE transcription . [14996792]
  • This suggests that during anaerobic-growth in liquid cultures in the absence of glucose , FNR is the major regulator of hlyE expression , and that CRP-mediated hlyE expression requires the presence of H-NS . [14996792]
  • The ﬁndings that SlyA does not enhance hlyE expression in hns cultures grown in liquid medium under anaerobic conditions and that SlyA appears unable to activate hlyE expression in the absence of FNR and CRP and the determination of the location of the region of PhlyE occupied by SlyA ( Fig. 6 ) suggest that SlyA activates hlyE expression by antagonizing the negative action of H-NS . [14996792]
  • Evidently , CRP , and not FNR , was required for the expression of ClyA in hns mutants under anoxic conditions , although it appeared that FNR could partly complement CRP . [11053378]
  • Under aerobic conditions with excess glucose , control of sdhCDAB -- b0725 -- sucABCD transcription by Arc , FNR , FruR and cAMP-CRP will play a minor role and , thus , reduced expression of this operon during glucose overflow metab-olism is likely due to the control by the cAMP-CRP independent catabolite control system . [17273855]
  • Therefore , we suggest that when environmental conditions dictate a low intra cellular concentration of H-NS , the H-NS I region of PhlyE is occupied to modulate the activity of the upstream activator ( FNR or CRP ) . [14996792]
  • This positive effect of H-NS was not observed under anaerobic conditions , presumably because FNR and not CRP occupies PhlyE under these conditions . [14996792]
  • Both FNR and CRP make positive contributions , whereas H-NS acts negatively under these conditions . [14996792]
  • For these conditions , we predicted that the glucose-responsive effects of CRP would be retained , whereas the positive regulation by FNR would be abolished . [14996792]
  • However , rather than the approximately eightfold enhancement in hlyE expression observed in an hns mutant on solid medium ( 36 ) , in liquid culture H-NS has a positive effect on CRP-driven hlyE expression , a negative effect on FNR-driven hlyE expression , and little intrinsic regulatory activity in the absence of FNR and CRP . [14996792]
  • Thus , CRP enhances hlyE expression in response to glucose-starvation ( 36 ) and FNR enhances hlyE expression in response to oxygen starvation ( 10 , 11 , 23 ) . [14996792]
  • In summary , the data presented here suggest that FNR and CRP are positive regulators of hlyE expression in liquid culture in response to oxygen and glucose-starvation , respectively . [14996792]
  • These data suggested that hlyE expression is activated by FNR and CRP , repressed by H-NS , and that H-NS-mediated transcriptional silencing is relieved by SlyA . [17892462]
  • By competing with H-NS for the region of PhlyE downstream of the FNR/CRP site , SlyA may prevent the formation of the negatively acting H-NS -- PhlyE complexes by blocking a primary interaction between H-NS and PhlyE , allowing FNR and CRP to continue to activate hlyE expression . [14996792]
  • Thus , we concluded that CRP , FNR , and H-NS all contribute towards the regulation of hlyE expression . [14996792]
  • Thus , CRP and FNR positively control cai expression and H-NS exerts a negative control . [9573142]
  • Thus , we suggest that the formation of different H-NS -- PhlyE complexes offers the opportunity for H-NS , in combination with FNR and CRP , to control hlyE expression both positively and negatively . [14996792]
  • These observations may be explained by a mechanism in which FNR recognizes PhlyE efﬁciently but acts only as a relatively poor activator of hlyE transcription ( 10 , 11 ) , whereas , conversely , the recognition of PhlyE by CRP is poor , but once CRP is bound , CRP-mediated activation of hlyE expression is efﬁcient . [14996792]

  • This is surprising because it was expected that tandem-bound FNR dimers would act synergistically to activate transcription , as has been reported for the closely related transcription factor CRP ( Savery et al. , 1996 ) . [11169114]
  • Thus the global regulators are proteins that control responses to changing food levels and carbon degradation ( mlc , lrp , CRP ) and transcription factors that respond to changes in redox status or ion levels of the cell ( arcA , narL , FNR , fur ) . [12582243]

  • It was therefore possible that the lack of derepression of the hcp promoter by externally added NO was due to compensating effects of NO-acti-vated derepression by NsrR and loss of activation by FNR . [22092912]
  • Three of the obvious possible explanations for the minimal response of the hcp promoter to external NO are that derepression of NsrR was counter-balanced by loss of transcription activation by FNR ; that derepression of the NsrR regulon resulted in sufﬁcient capacity to repair nitrosative damage to FNR as rapidly as it occurred or that the capacity of the bacteria to reduce NO was sufﬁcient to prevent its cytoplasmic accumulation . [22092912]

  • The interaction of FNR-AR1 and FNR-AR3 with RNAP is apparently altered by NarL and/or IHF Although some FNR-dependent promoters appear to use only FNR for transcription activation , other promoters , such as PnarG , require the additional factors NarL and IHF for maximal expression ( Rabin et al. , 1992 ; Stewart , 1993 ) . [11115116]
  • Thus , these data suggest that the regions of FNR disrupted by the FNR-AR1 and FNR-AR3 mutants can account for the majority of the transcription activation of PnarG and PdmsA in the absence of nitrate . [11115116]
  • However , it appears that the role of NarL at PnarG is more direct , as transcription activation of PnarG can not be detected in vitro , unless FNR , IHF and NarL are all present ( E. C. Ziegelhoffer and P. J. Kiley , unpublished ) . [11115116]
  • The molecular mechanism by which NarL , IHF and FNR function together to stimulate transcription activation at PnarG is not known . [11115116]
  • In the absence of oxygen , the oxygen-sensitive global regulators ArcA and FNR mediate the repression of many TCA promoters , but most dramatically the sdh-suc operon , which encodes SDH , KDGH , and the SCSC ( 104 , 105 , 170 , 293 , 335 , 339 , 406 ) . [15755952]
  • Furthermore , the regulatory outcome is essentially reciprocal in that FNR usually activates transcription , whereas ArcA generally acts as a negative regulator . [20075074]
  • Other studies have shown that ArcA functions to activate cy-dAB transcription as oxygen becomes limiting ( 19 , 20 ) , whereas FNR is required for repression when the oxygen tension is decreased further ( 18 , 21 , 22 ) . [12754220]
  • Subsequent studies have shown that ArcA functions to anti-repress cydAB transcription when oxygen is limiting ( 46 ) , whereas FNR is required for repression when the oxygen tension is decreased further ( 14 , 17 , 45 ) . [15699038]
  • Although the roles of FNR and ArcA in mediating the changes in transcript profiles necessary for adaptation to growth at different oxygen availabilities are well established ( see above ) , the consequent changes in physiology are expected to modulate the activities of other transcription factors that respond to specific metabolic signals that are affected by oxygen availability . [21252224]

  • This effect is compounded by the fact that arcA transcription is directly activated by FNR ( 5 ) , which in turn is essential for oxidation of ubiquinol by the cytoplasmic or periplasmic nitrate reducta-ses , NarG or Nap . [16377617]
  • In some of these cases , however , apparent regulation was based on promoter fusion data and might therefore be indirect , for example , due to an effect of FNR on arcA transcription . [16417494]
  • As concluded previously by Gruer & Guest ( 1994 ) , the effect of FNR is not simply due to its known ability to activate arcA transcription ( Compan & Touati , 1994 ) . [9421904]
  • Thus , nitrosylation of iron atoms , especially ironsulfur clusters , in enzymes such as aconitase and fumarase or in the transcription factors FNR , Fur , SoxR , OxyR , and NsrR inactivates their functions . [22029434]
  • Whereas the effect on Fur and FNR caused transcription alterations in the genes under their control , that of SoxR was unexpected ; although a large increase upon the transcription of soxS occurred , a corresponding increase on the SoxRS regulon could not be detected . [15546870]
  • Indeed , the homology between FNR and CRP is such that their DNA-binding specificities can be interconverted by appropriate substitutions in the recognition helices , such that catabolite repression can be lifted in response to anoxia and anaerobic gene activation can be induced by glucose-starvation ( cAMP ) ] 7 . [1957353]
  • In E. coli , operons caiTABCDE and fixABCX are modulated positively by general regulators , such as the AMPc receptor protein ( CRP ) or the transcriptional-regulator responsible for anaerobic induction ( FNR ) , and negatively by the DNA-binding protein H-NS , glucose , or nitrate ( Eichler et al. , 1994a ; Unden and Trageser 1991 ) . [14595781]
  • Its expression is also dependent on the global regulatory proteins mediating catabolic repression via cyclic AMP receptor protein ( CRP ) , or anaerobiosis via fumarate nitrate reduction ( FNR ) transcriptional-regulator , and the nucleoid-associated DNA-binding protein H-NS . [8631699]
  • Moreover , it is subject to global control by the same regulatory proteins which are known to modulate expression of carnitine metabolism , i.e. , the cyclic AMP ( cAMP ) receptor protein ( CRP ) which mediates the activation of catabolic operons , the transcriptional-regulator FNR that is responsible for anaerobic induction , and the DNA-binding protein H-NS ( 19 , 10 ) . [9573142]

  • Perspectives The transcription of nik genes is stimulated by the global regulator FNR under anoxic conditions , and negatively controlled by a new repressor protein , NikR , responding specifically to Ni . [10648098]
  • The purpose of this genome-based study is to identify additional genes differentially expressed in response to oxygen availability and to define further the network of genes controlled by the global regulatory protein , FNR . [12754220]
  • The aerobic requirement for FNR is surprising because the iron ^ sulfur-con-taining holo-FNR protein activates the expression of an-aerobic genes in response to oxygen-starvation , but does not bind at these target promoters when oxygen is available ( reviewed in [ 8 ^ 11 ] ) . [14612240]
  • The FNR protein induces expression anaerobically , and evidence indicates that it probably binds to a specific recognition sequence located around position -40 bp relative to the transcription initiation site ( 41 ) . [8376324]
  • The consensus sequence for FNR is similar to that for CRP consensus , and previous studies have shown that FNR activates transcription initiation in a similar way to CRP and that both proteins can bind to the DNA site for the other protein ( 41,42 ) . [15520470]
  • The unbound FNR protein in the cell can bind to lower affinity targets including moe DNA and repress its transcription when the demand for Mo-cofactor and Moe proteins is low . [11357510]
  • The possibility that the binding of heterodimers has an effect on transcription regulation was judged unlikely following another control experiment in which heterodimers of FNR-E209V and wild-type FNR were co-expressed . [11169114]
  • The regulation of yhjA expression is interesting , because transcription is dependent on two transcription factors , FNR and OxyR , that respond to two seemingly incompatible signals , i.e. oxygen starvation and peroxide stress . [17464064]
  • The ability of FNR to activate transcription was observed to be impaired by iron deprivation , and the relationship between nutritional iron status and oxygen sensing led to speculation that an iron co-factor was involved in sensing of oxygen levels 19 . [8871401]
  • The FNR protein activates transcription in response to anaerobiosis . [2168848]

  • Regulation by O2 is effected by the O2 sensorregulators FNR and ArcArB w4 ,9,61 -- 63x , regulation by nitrate by the sensor-regulators NarXrL and NarPrQ w6 ,8 x . [9230919]
  • Thus , FNR can respond to not only O2 , but also NO , with major implications for global gene regulation in bacteria . [12093725]
  • An iron cofactor ( Fe2 § of FNR appears to be essential in the process of O2-sensing and O2-dependent regulation . [1854188]

  • The reverse reaction , the formation of active FNR is assumed to be slow and to represent the sum of de novo synthesis of FNR and of the reactivation of O2-inactivated FNR . [11931557]

  • Therefore it is assumed that the inactivation of FNR by O2 essentially is responsible for the control of the functional state of FNR , or the ratio of active and inactive FNR . [11931557]
  • 1 this can be explained assuming that the inactivation of FNR by O is rapid compared to the formation of active FNR , and that the inactivation varies largely in response to the O2 concentration . [11931557]
  • Therefore at O2 concentrations as low as 1 mM in the medium , sufﬁcient O2 should be present in the cytoplasm for FNR inactivation . [11931557]
  • Therefore in vitro FNR can be inactivated by O2 and reactivated in a cyclic process as shown in Figure 1 , and in this way O2 inactivation of FNR is reversible . [11931557]
  • According to this model the functional state of FNR is determined by a ( rapid ) inactivation of FNR by O , and a slow ( constant ) 2 reactivation with glutathione as the reducing agent . [11931557]

  • Determination of the afinity of Fld1 , Fld2 , and Fd for FNR To determine the afinity of Fd , Fld1 , and Fld2 for FNR , we examined UV -- visible spectra of FNR as increasing amounts of each protein was added . [12234497]
  • Using the protein concentrations determined above and known extinction coeficients , the predicted contribution due to Fd , Fld1 , or Fld2 was subtracted , and the remaining increase in absorbance at 460 nm was attributed to changes in the FAD cofactor of FNR . [12234497]
  • We examined binding by following changes in the spectrum of the FAD cofactor in FNR as increasing concentrations of Fld1 , Fld2 , or Fd were added . [12234497]
  • Overall , these results suggest that while FNR can bind each potential electron transfer partner , binding to Fd is thermodynamically favored over Fld1 and Fld2 . [12234497]
  • Total observed spectral changes are normalized to facilitate plotting on the same scale and are ﬁt with rate constants of Fd , 8.4 s 1 ; Fld1 , 7.5 and 25 s 1 ; and Fld2 , 1.2 and 8.7 s 1 Fd facilitates electron transfer into Fld1 and Fld2 Since Fd binds tightly with FNR , we considered the possibility that Fd might inhibit binding of Fld to FNR , and further slow the rate of Fld reduction . [12234497]
  • Since Fd was prereduced to equilibrium with FNR and NADPH and is rapidly rereduced following electron transfer , Fd contributes little to the observed absorbance changes . [12234497]

  • In N-oxide sensing and denitrification transcription factor ( DNR ; effector NO ) , a member of the CAP/FNR superfamily for which a structure of the isolated effector-binding domain in the absence of effector is available ( 27 ) , the C-helix and the intersubunit C-helix/C - helix coiled coil seem to be partly unstructured in the absence of effector and to extend only to the residue corresponding to Gln-125 in CAP . [19359484]
  • This is followed by an intra-protein electron transfer from the reductase domain ( or FNR , ferredoxin-NADP reductase-like domain ) to the N-terminal heme domain in an NAD ( P ) H-dependent reaction via a non-covalently bound FAD allowing the reconversion of the oxidized heme ( ferric , Fe ( III ) ) to the reduced ( ferrous , ( FeII ) ) form and consequent continuation of catalytic-activity ( 26 , 32 , 33 ) . [25193663]

  • While we were preparing this report , Crack et al. ( 7 ) reported that H2O2 was produced from the reaction of FNR with O2 , which led to the proposal of a reaction mechanism where two cluster irons are oxidized to Fe3 during O2-induced cluster conversion to provide the two electrons to produce H2O2 from O2 . [15547274]
  • This result also suggests that although covalently linking two FNR monomers enhances dimerization by locating the two monomers in close proximity , it does not suppress the dimerization induced by the assembly of the [ 4Fe -- 4S ] 2 + cluste which is spontaneous in vivo . [22326866]
  • To investigate the effect of superoxide on 2Fe-FNR turnover in vivo , we were limited to whole-cell methods that monitor the status of the Fe-S cluster ( since 2Fe-FNR has no known in vivo activity ) , and all such available methods require the overexpression of FNR . [14730984]
  • While this cluster is reactive with superoxide , we have no evidence that FNR plays any role in the well-known adaptive response to superoxide stress , since 2Fe-FNR has no known transcription activity . [14730984]
  • Isolated 2Fe-FNR Contains a [ 2Fe-2S ] 2 + Cluster and Is Monomeric in Solution . [14730984]
  • [ 2Fe -- 2S ] FNR is no longer active in transcriptional activation . [11931557]
  • However , the destabilization of the [ 2Fe-2S ] cluster of FNR with superoxide is not a general property of [ 2Fe-2S ] proteins since imposing a superoxide stress on SoxR results only in a change in cluster oxidation state ( from [ 2Fe-2S ] 1 + to [ 2Fe-2S ] 2 + ) , which converts SoxR into an active transcription factor ( 23 ) . [14730984]
  • However , the [ 2Fe-2S ] 2 + cluster of FNR does not contain any iron lacking a cysteinyl ligand like that of the hydrolyase clusters , and thus the decomposition of 2Fe-FNR is likely to show some differences from that of the hydrolyase clusters . [14730984]
  • By quantifying the amount of [ 2Fe-2S ] 2 + cluster in 2Fe-FNR in vitro in the presence of various reductants and oxidants ( GSH , DTT , cysteine , O2 , hydrogen peroxide , and superoxide ) , we found that superoxide , a byproduct of aerobic metabolism , significantly destabilized the [ 2Fe-2S ] 2 + cluster . [14730984]
  • The loss of the [ 2Fe-2S ] cluster from purified 2Fe-FNR was monitored as a decrease in absorption at 550 nm . [14730984]
  • To further characterize the destruction of the [ 2Fe-2S ] cluster of FNR , the Fe3 + - specific chelator Tiron was used to monitor release of Fe3 + from the [ 2Fe-2S ] 2 + cluster during the reaction with superoxide . [14730984]
  • It can be seen that the doublet representing 2Fe-FNR has essentially disappeared , i.e. , the [ 2Fe-2S ] 2 + cluster has been destroyed by the formation of superoxide . [14730984]
  • We conclude that the [ 2Fe-2S ] 2 + cluster of FNR is labile to superoxide both in vitro and in vivo . [14730984]
  • Oxidation of FNR by oxygen in vitro : formation of the [ 2Fe-2S ] cluster ... 6 . [9990723]
  • Determining the in vitro rates of cluster conversion also allowed us to assess whether these values were compatible with in vivo measurements of FNR inactivation . [15547274]
  • It has yet to be determined whether the form of FNR containing the [ 2Fe-2S ] 21 cluster has any biological significance , e.g. , as an in vivo intermediate that is more rapidly converted to the active form than the apoprotein . [9177174]
  • Such information will be important in determining whether the 2Fe cluster form of FNR is a physiologically relevant intermediate in the activation/deactivation of FNR in vivo . [9990723]
  • Nonetheless , whether it is the 2Fe form or apoprotein ( or some combination of both ) that is the substrate in vivo , activation of FNR will likely require additional proteins that facilitate Fe-S cluster assembly . [9990723]
  • With FNR we now have a 4Fe 3 2Fe conversion occurring simply with a pure protein exposed to air in an aqueous solution at neutral pH. Since the 2Fe form appears relatively stable in the presence of air ( half-life at least 12 h at 0 ° C ) and this cluster ( or its components ) could be used to regenerate the 4Fe form in vitro , it is possible that the 2Fe form could have some physiological relevance if the 2Fe form was more readily reactivated in vivo . [9177174]
  • As described in the following sections , a simple change in the redox state of the [ 4Fe-4S ] 2 cluster to the expected 1 + oxidation state is not the physiologically relevant redox reaction for FNR ; the cluster is very di $ cult to reduce to the +1 oxidation state in vitro and no physiological electron donors or acceptors have been identi cents ed that would maintain the cluster in the +1 oxidation state under anaerobic conditions . [9990723]
  • FNR , another Fe -- S transcription factor in E. coli , only forms dimers and binds DNA in the presence of its oxygen-labile [ 4Fe-4S ] cluster .8,31 SoxR , a [ 2Fe -- 2S ] - containing transcription activator in the MerR-family , can bind its single target DNA site in the presence or absence of its Fe -- S cluster . [19361432]
  • Molecular modeling suggests a mechanism by which Phe at position 24 protects the FNR [ 4Fe-4S ] 2 cluster and that Cys-23 or the iron bound to it is a primary site of O2 interaction with the [ 4Fe-4S ] 2 cluster . [19261852]
  • In summary , we have demonstrated a 2-step mechanism for the FNR [ 4Fe-4S ] 2 to [ 2Fe-2S ] 2 cluster conversion via a [ 3Fe-4S ] intermediate , shown that the residue at position 24 in FNR modulates the reaction of the [ 4Fe-4S ] 2 cluster with O2 , and formulated a plausible molecular model that suggests that 2 O2 interacts with the FNR [ 4Fe-4S ] cluster in the vicinity of Cys-23 . [19261852]
  • Reversal of cluster conversion When oxygen-treated FNR was made anaerobic and reduced by dithionite , Moëssbauer spectroscopy showed that the [ 4Fe-4S ] 2 cluster was regenerated in 90 % yield on the basis of total cluster iron , that is , two 2Fe clusters apparently reformed one 4Fe cluster [ 24 ] . [9990723]
  • We report here the unexpected observation that the [ 4Fe-4S ] cluster of FNR is converted in less than 5 min to a [ 2Fe-2S ] cluster in about 60 % yield as judged from Mössbauer spectra and this conversion results in a reduction in DNA-binding ability . [9177174]
  • We also found that , on reaction of FNR with air , the [ 4Fe-4S ] 21 cluster decayed and a new cluster species was formed in high yield ( 60 -- 65 % ) , which , according to UVyVIS and Mössbauer spectroscopies , exhibited properties of [ 2Fe-2S ] 21 clusters . [9177174]
  • Our current understanding is that FNR is continually supplied with [ 4Fe-4S ] 2 clusters by the iron -- sulfur cluster biosynthetic machinery ( 25 -- 27 ) , but O2 converts the [ 4Fe-4S ] 2 cluster to a [ 3Fe-4S ] cluster that spontaneously disassembles to yield a [ 2Fe-2S ] 2 cluster with concomitant inactivation of FNR ( 12 , 15 , 22 , 23 ) . [19261852]
  • The present study shows that the predominant form of FNR in aerobic cells is apo-FNR ( cluster-less FNR ) indicating that the [ 2Fe-2S ] 2 + cluster , like the [ 4Fe-4S ] 2 + cluster , is not stable under these conditions . [14730984]
  • Khoroshilova N , Popescu C , Münck E , Beinert H & Kiley PJ ( 1997 ) Iron-sulfur cluster disassembly in the FNR protein of Escherichia coli by O2 : [ 4Fe-4S ] to [ 2Fe-2S ] conversion with loss of biological activity . [22029434]
  • Apparently , [ 2Fe-2S ] - and [ 4Fe-4S ] - contain-ing FNR showed similar sensitivities to the displacement of the FeS cluster , and both forms were not differentiated in the labeling studies . [18055593]
  • The O2 sensitivity of FNR is also mediated by the [ 4Fe-4S ] 2 cluster ; in the presence of O , the [ 4Fe-4S ] 2 2 cluster is converted to a [ 2Fe-2S ] 2 cluster both in vitro and in vivo ( 15 , 16 , 24 ) . [15547274]
  • Thus , the lack of 2Fe-FNR in aerobic cells is difficult to explain by lability of the [ 2Fe-2S ] cluster to O2 as has been previously observed with the [ 4Fe-4S ] cluster ( 4 , 19 ) . [14730984]
  • In the presence of O2 , conversion of the [ 4Fe-4S ] 2 + cluster to a [ 2Fe-2S ] 2 + cluster inactivates FNR , but the fate of the [ 2Fe-2S ] 2 + cluster in cells grown under aerobic conditions is unknown . [14730984]
  • In the presence of O2 , the [ 4Fe-4S ] 2 cluster is converted to a [ 2Fe-2S ] 2 cluster , which inactivates FNR as a transcriptional regulator . [15547274]
  • As a ﬁrst step , we developed an assay to monitor the [ 4Fe-4S ] 2 cluster to [ 2Fe-2S ] 2 cluster conversion under conditions where O2 could be added in excess relative to 4Fe-FNR and where product formation could be easily monitored in real time . [15547274]
  • Upon exposure to O2 , FNR is inactivated by conversion of the [ 4Fe-4S ] 2 + cluster to a [ 2Fe-2S ] 2 + cluster , which produces the 2Fe-FNR form . [14730984]
  • Kinetic analysis of the oxidative conversion of the [ 4Fe -- 4S ] cluster of FNR 2 + to a [ 2Fe -- 2S ] cluster . [17464064]
  • Kinetic analysis of the oxidative conversion of the [ 4Fe-4S ] 2 cluster of FNR to a [ 2Fe-2S ] 2 cluster . [20709841, 25266384, 17293415]

  • Kinetic analysis of the oxidative conversion of the [ 4Fe-4S ] 2 + cluster of FNR to a [ 2Fe-2S ] 2 + cluster . [23075318]
  • Since our previous Mössbauer analyses of the cluster conversion process 2 suggested that Fe is one product of the reaction of 4Fe-FNR with O2 ( 16 , 24 ) , we examined the effectiveness of using the Fe2 - speciﬁc chelator ferene to monitor reaction progress . [15547274]
  • In our previous analysis of the cluster conversion process , we found that only 70 % of the sulﬁde originally in the cluster was detectable following the treatment of 4Fe-FNR with O2 ( 16 ) . [15547274]
  • Acknowledging the stated assumptions , we conclude that O2-dependent cluster conversion of 4Fe-FNR can reasonably explain the loss of FNR activity by O2 in vivo . [15547274]
  • For FNR prepared with naturally abundant iron , a maximal [ 4Fe-4S ] cluster content of 0.50 -- 0.58 mol per mol of FNR monomer was obtained , whereas the samples labeled with 57Fe contained 0.76 and 0.59 mol [ 4Fe-4S ] cluster per mol of FNR monomer . [9177174]
  • To test whether the anaerobically functional dimer of ( FNRD154A ) 2 was still dependent on the [ 4Fe -- 4S ] 2 + cluster and thus retains the O2 sensing capability , we introduced C122A , which has been shown to abolish the [ 4Fe -- 4S ] 2 + cluster binding and transcription activity upon introduction to native FNR [ 16 ] . [22326866]
  • The ability of FNR to function as a transcription factor depends on the integrity of a [ 4Fe-4S ] 2 cluster , which promotes a conformation that is necessary for FNR dimerization , site-speciﬁc DNA-binding , and transcriptional regulation ( 12 , 16 , 19 , 21 ) . [15547274]
  • Assembly of the [ 4Fe -- 4S ] 2 + cluster results in simultaneous FNR dimerization and activity of speciﬁc DNA-binding and transcription regulation [ 3 ] . [22326866]
  • The [ 4Fe ± 4S ] 2 + cluster of FNR is oxygen labile and controls protein dimerization and site-speci ® c DNA-binding . [12093725]
  • FNR has an O2-sensitive [ 4Fe-4S ] 2 cluster that directly senses O2 and regulates site-speciﬁc DNA-binding ( 40 ) . [15659690]
  • By removal of the cluster with a Fe chelator , Lazazzera et al. also showed that the [ 4Fe-4S ] cluster was responsible for the increased dimerization and site-spe-ci cents c DNA-binding that was observed with anaerobically puri cents ed FNR [ 16 ] . [9990723]
  • Under anaerobic conditions , acquisition of 1 [ 4Fe-4S ] 2 cluster per FNR protomer causes dimerization and enhances site-specific DNA-binding ( 15 ) . [19261852]
  • Under anaerobic conditions FNR contains a [ 4Fe -- 4S ] cluster that promotes dimerization of the protein and enhances site-speciﬁc DNA-binding ( Lazazzera et al. , 1996 ) . [17464064]
  • We have investigated whether DNA-binding and the spectral characteristics of the protein containing the [ 4Fe-4S ] cluster could be restored to the air-oxidized ( 10 min ) FNR by reconstitution ( see above , Materials and Methods ) . [9177174]
  • Previously , we observed that brief exposure of anaerobic FNR preparations to air caused a decrease in both specific DNA-binding and the absorption spectrum characteristic of a [ 4Fe-4S ] cluster ( 3 ) . [9177174]
  • While it is known that the [ 4Fe-4S ] 2 cluster of FNR is required for DNA-binding , we are not aware of any experiments that have addressed whether DNA-binding inﬂuences the rate of O - induced [ 4Fe-4S ] 2 cluster conversion . [15547274]
  • Therefore , we conclude that the interaction of DNA with 4Fe-FNR does not substantially inﬂuence the susceptibility of the [ 4Fe-4S ] 2 cluster to O2 . [15547274]
  • To obtain oxygen stable FNR variants for in vitro characterizations , in this study , we utilized the approach of covalently linking two fnr alleles in tandem to promote their in situ dimerization in the absence of the [ 4Fe -- 4S ] 2 + cluster under aerobic conditions . [22326866]
  • Replacing aspartic acid with alanine in FNRD154A eliminates charge repulsions between the two FNR monomers and thus improves its dimerization in the absence of the [ 4Fe -- 4S ] 2 + cluster under aerobic conditions [ 8 ] . [22326866]
  • Under conditions of very low oxygen tension , most of FNR will be in the dimeric state and will contain the 4Fe cluster , with the remainder of FNR being in the monomeric state as apoprotein . [9990723]
  • This review will describe these recent cents ndings : namely , what led to the discovery of a [ 4Fe-4S ] cluster in FNR and how this metal cluster functions in oxygen sensing by FNR both in vitro and in vivo . [9990723]
  • Furthermore , we found that the [ 4Fe-4S ] 21 cluster in wild-type FNR was very difficult to reduce , suggesting that its redox potential is rather low and that such a reduced cluster ( 11 oxidation state ) would not occur in vivo ( see above and ref . [9177174]
  • Attempts to reduce the [ 4Fe-4S ] 2 cluster of FNR with dithionite indicated that the redox potential of the +1 / +2 couple is 9 3650 mV and that the [ 4Fe-4S ] cluster form is , therefore , not likely to occur in vivo . [9990723]
  • We have thus further supported our proposed model for the function of FNR , namely that the active form of the FNR protein contains a [ 4Fe-4S ] 21 cluster , and that this cluster serves as the O2 sensor by virtue of its extreme sensitivity toward O2 . [9177174]
  • Previous analysis of an FNR mutant protein ( 2 ) suggests that sensitivity toward O2 is primarily determined by subtle details of protein structure , since substitution of Leu-28 for His allowed for purification in the presence of oxygen of FNR containing a [ 4Fe-4S ] cluster . [9177174]
