  • The [ 4Fe-4S ] 21 cluster of FNR was not reduced by dithionite , even at pH 9 and in the presence of methylviologen , indicating a very low redox potential . [9177174]
  • The electronic spectra obtained upon addition of dithionite to FNR containing the [ 4Fe-4S ] 2 cluster indicate at least partial reduction of the cluster to the 1 + state [ 34 ] . [9990723]
  • Our data showed that this form of FNR contained a [ 4Fe-4S ] 21 cluster ( d 5 0.45 mmys ; DEQ 5 1.22 mmys ) and that the [ 4Fe-4S ] 21 cluster was rapidly destroyed on exposure of FNR to air . [9177174]
  • Recent data suggest that FNR contains a [ 4Fe-4S ] cluster ( 2 -- 4 ) and that this cluster apparently mediates the sensitivity of this transcription factor to oxygen , thus limiting FNR activity to anaerobic conditions . [9177174]
  • FNR is located in the cytoplasm and contains a [ 4Fe -- 4S ] cluster in the active ( anaerobic ) state . [11931557]
  • Thus , our data show that anaerobically purified FNR contains a [ 4Fe-4S ] 21 cluster . [9177174]
  • Recent progress in this field has shown that anaerobically purified FNR contains a [ 4Fe-4S ] 2 cluster and that this [ 4Fe-4S ] 2 cluster is sufficiently unstable toward O2 to make it suitable as an O2 sensor . [9990723]
  • Thus it seems likely that the anaerobic activation of FNR requires the de novo incorporation of a [ 4Fe-4S ] 2 + cluster into apo-FNR . [11407111]
  • Reduction of the [ 4Fe-4S ] 2 + cluster FNR puri cents ed under anaerobic conditions has been shown by Mo ëssbauer spectroscopy to contain a [ 4Fe-4S ] cluster in the 2 + form . [9990723]
  • FNR is a homodimeric DNA-bind-ing protein containing approximately one [ 4Fe-4S ] 2 cluster per subunit ( called 4Fe-FNR ) ( 3 , 16 , 19 ) . [15547274]
  • Under anaerobic conditions , FNR exists in a transcriptionally active form that consists of a homodimeric complex containing one [ 4Fe-4S ] 2 + cluster per subunit ( herein called 4Fe-FNR ) 1 ( 3 , 4 ) . [14730984]
  • Role of the Fe-S cluster in dimerization FNR puri cents ed from anaerobic cells is a dimer containing one [ 4Fe-4S ] 2 cluster per subunit [ 24 ] . [9990723]
  • Rather it appears that the form of FNR as isolated ( [ 4Fe-4S ] 2 cluster ) is the relevant form and the presence of this cluster stabilizes a conformation of FNR that is able to dimerize and bind DNA site-speci cents cally . [9990723]
  • However , it is not understood how the presence of the [ 4Fe-4S ] 2 cluster increases dimerization of FNR . [9990723]
  • If one accepts the structure of the CAP protein as model for that of FNR , then it seems that the presence of the [ 4Fe-4S ] cluster causes FNR to adopt a speci cents c conformation which is favorable for dimerization . [9990723]
  • From the stoichiometries of iron and sulfide relative to the number of cysteine residues of anaerobically purified FNR ( 3 ) , we had previously concluded that FNR contains one [ 4Fe-4S ] rather than two [ 2Fe-2S ] clusters per monomer . [9177174]
  • The stoichiometry of iron and labile sulfide relative to the number of cysteine ligands of anaerobically purified FNR is most compatible with the presence of a [ 4Fe-4S ] cluster ( 3 ) . [9177174]
  • Previous determinations of Fe and S22 stoichiometries of anaerobically purified FNR ( 3 ) relative to the number of cysteine residues have suggested that the most likely type of cluster present in anaerobic preparations of FNR is a [ 4Fe-4S ] 21 cluster . [9177174]
  • Under anoxic conditions , FNR is a dimer and carries a [ 4Fe -- 4S ] 2 + cluster per monomer ( [ 4Fe -- 4S ] FNR ) which is bound by 4 cysteine residues . [11931557]
  • Here we studied the formation and presence of apoFNR in aerobically and anaerobically growing E. coli in situ by differentiating apoFNR from [ 2Fe-2S ] FNR and [ 4Fe-4S ] FNR using a method for measuring the accessibility of the Cys residues to thiol reagents ( 1 ) . [18055593]
  • Up to ﬁve Cys residues are accessible to thiol reagents in apoFNR , whereas only Cys16 is accessible in [ 4Fe-4S ] FNR and [ 2Fe-2S ] FNR ; the other four Cys residues are ligands of the Fe-S clusters in [ 4Fe-4S ] FNR and [ 2Fe-2S ] FNR and are thereby protected from labeling . [18055593]
  • Since [ 4Fe-4S ] FNR and [ 2Fe-2S ] FNR require the same number of Cys residues ( four ) for liganding the FeS cluster , the difference should indicate increased amounts of apoFNR . [18055593]
  • In vitro , air inactivation of [ 4Fe-4S ] FNR yields apoFNR with 1.5 Cys-disulﬁde residues ( 1 ) . [18055593]
  • Before the presence and function of the [ 4Fe-4S ] cluster in FNR was known , the Cys residues of aerobically growing E. coli were shown to be more readily accessible to alkylation than those from anaerobically growing E. coli ( 35 ) . [18055593]
  • Thus , we modeled residues Cys-20 -- Cys-29 of FNR with a [ 4Fe-4S ] cluster bound by using SWISS-Model ( 38 -- 42 ) and endonuclease III as a template . [19261852]
  • Thus , apoFNR , which was reduced by DTT , and reconstituted [ 4Fe-4S ] FNR showed the same Mr of 34,000 after labeling by AMS , suggesting that AMS replaces the FeS cluster and labels FNR at up to ﬁve Cys residues . [18055593]
  • 23 and 29 ) , together with the single internal cysteine ( Cys122 ) , represent the ` cysteine signature ' that is essential for FNR function ( Melville and Gunsalus , 1990 ; Sharrocks et al. , 1990 ) , presumably by providing the ligands tk ) r assembly of the [ 4Fe-4S ] cluster assembly . [11407111]
  • The cluster ligands for the [ 4Fe-4S ] cluster of FNR are presumed to be Cys20 , Cys23 , Cys29 and Cys122 since mutational analysis of these residues has shown that they are required for FNR function in vivo [ 10,12 ] and these mutant proteins lack iron and sul - cents de upon puri cents cation ( Khoroshilova et al. , unpublished data ) . [9990723]
  • The E. coli strain JRG1728 ( vlac , vfnr ) containing pGS1483 was then transformed with either pGS196 , an fnr expression plasmid ; pGS198 , an equivalent plasmid encoding an FNR protein that is unable to sense and respond to oxygen-starvation , because it lacks three of the four cysteine residues that ligate the [ 4Fe-4S ] cluster ; or the vector pBR322t ( Table 1 ) . [14612240]
  • The exact molecular basis of the enhanced oxygen sensitivity of the [ 4Fe-4S ] cluster and sensory capacity of CydR is unknown but it could be due to differences in amino sequence of the N-terminal region of CydR relative to E. coli FNR , where substitutions in non-liganding residues are known to affect cluster stability ( see section 2.3.2 ) . [11407111]
  • So , it would appear that histidine residues in the N-terminal region of FNR improve the stability of the [ 4Fe-4SI cluster , and that the presence of three histidine residues in this region of FIpA may have a similar stabilizing effect . [11407111]
  • At the amino acid level , CydR is 50 % identical to E. coli FNR and it retains the DNA-binding specificity of FNR and the four cysteine ligands involved in [ 4Fe-4S ] cluster acquisition by FNR . [11407111]
  • A number of FNR homologues have been identiﬁed and are characterized by the presence of four essential cysteine residues that act as ligands for the [ 4Fe -- 4S ] 2þ cluster , and the amino acid sequence E -- SR in the DNA-binding helix , which confers speciﬁcity for the FNR ope-rator sequence TTGAT -- ATCAA ( Guest et al. , 1996 ) . [9767578]
  • Despite lacking two of the N-terminal cysteine residues that are essential in FNR , FlpA was found to acquire [ 4Fe-4S ] clusters under anaerobic conditions and their incorporation was accompanied by the loss of the DNA-binding activity ( Scott et al. , 2000 ) . [11407111]
  • It is easy to envisage the conversion of an anaerobic transcription factor like FNR to an FlpA-like factor simply by replacing two of the N-terminal cysteine residues by histidine to generate a more stable [ 4Fe-4S ] protein ( and vice versa ) . [11407111]
  • It is interesting to note that the molar extinction coefficients of the [ 2Fe-2S ] Rieske iron-sulfur proteins ( which have two cysteine and two histidine ligands ) are lower than those of proteins with ` all-cysteinyl ' [ 2Fe-2S ] clusters ( Fee et al. , 1984 ) , because the molar extinction coefficient of the [ 4Fe-4S ] form of FIpA is also low compared with that of reconstituted FNR , which would be consistent with the use of Rieske-like liganding in FlpA . [11407111]
  • The transition from active FNR containing cubic [ 4Fe-4S ] 2 + clusters to inactive forms , having planar [ 2Fe-2S ] 2 + clusters or no clusters , presumably involves substantial rearrangement of the essential cysteine ligands , which in turn could drive the dimer-monomer transition and thus inactivate the transcriptionally active DNA-binding protein . [11407111]
  • The accompanying rearrangement of the cysteine ligands in moving from a cubic [ 4Fe-4S ] z + cluster to a planar [ 2Fe-2S ] 2 + cluster drives the dimer to monomer transition and consequent loss of biological activity.Apo-FNR [ 4SH ] ( excludingthe non-essential Cys16 sulfhydryl ) can be reversibly oxidized to a disulfide form [ 2SH , S-S ] , suggesting that FNR may be able to sense oxidative stress as well as normoxia . [11407111]
  • Nevertheless , if the acquisition of the iron -- sulphur is not simply fortuitous or for purely structural purposes , cluster assembly and the potential for reversible disulphide and dimer formation could provide functional switches for DNA-binding and transcription regulation analogous to those operating in FNR and FLP . [11101674]
  • By analogy with FNR and FLP ( the FNR-like protein of Lactobacillus casei ) it was suggested that the transcriptionregulatory activity of YeiL might be modulated by a sensory iron -- sulphur cluster and/or by reversible disulphide bond formation . [11101674]
  • By analogy with FNR and FLP the DNA-binding form of YeiL might be dimeric and its activity might likewise be modulated by a sensory iron -- sulphur cluster , by reversible dithiol -- disulphide formation , or by both mechanisms . [11101674]
  • To correlate DNA-binding ability with the amount of the Fe-S cluster present in FNR , we examined changes in the Fe-S cluster content after exposure of the protein to air by UV-visible , EPR , and Mössbauer spectros-copies and by analyses for Fe , inorganic sulfide , and protein . [9177174]
  • In these latter two cases , DNA-binding is restored , thus indicating that these two forms of FNR appear to be similar and , at least by this criterion , no additional factors are required for FNR activity except for those required for cluster assembly ( e.g. , NifS ) . [9990723]
  • WT-FNR requires the 21 [ 4Fe24S ] cluster for dimerization and DNA-binding , whereas the 21 mutant , FNR-D154A ( open circle ) , which is used in our in vitro experiments , does not . [11115116]
  • In contrast to WT-FNR , FNR-D154A does not require a [ 4Fe24S ] cluster 21 for dimerization and DNA-binding under aerobic conditions ( Ziegelhoffer and Kiley , 1995 ; Lazazzera et al. , 1996 ) . [11115116]
  • The presence of the Fe-S cluster in the anaerobically purified form of FNR is correlated with an increase in dimerization and specific DNA-binding ( 3 ) , compared with the aerobically purified form that lacks an Fe-S cluster ( 2 , 5 , 6 ) . [9177174]
  • In the presence of O2 , FNR is converted into a monomeric , non-DNA-binding form containing a [ 2Fe-2S ] 2 cluster . [19261852]
  • Nevertheless , this [ 2Fe-2S ] 2 + cluster species of FNR was inactive for site-specific DNA-binding and appeared to be in a monomeric form ( 3 ) . [14730984]
  • Here , we report the reactivity of the iron -- sulfur cluster of an FNR protein with a single amino acid substitution , S24F , adjacent to a Cys cluster ligand and show that the replacement inhibits both the O2-dependent and O2-independent steps of cluster conversion . [19261852]
  • We used a mutated version of FNR , lacking amino acid residues 2 to 15 ( FNRΔ2 -- 15 ) , whose cluster is more stable to O2 than the wt protein ( Yan and Kiley , 2008 ) . [25430730]
  • The cluster is destroyed within seconds upon exposure to oxygen and an apoprotein devoid of the cluster is the product of the reaction2 ~ Interestingly , the discovery that an iron-sulfur cluster was the key to function did not occur until several mutants of FNR were analysed22 . [8871401]
  • Thus , these data suggest that the FNR iron -- sulfur cluster is stabilized by the presence of Phe at position 24 . [19261852]
  • Thus , the presence of Phe at position 24 does not impair the ability of FNR to bind an iron -- sulfur cluster with properties very similar to the [ 4Fe-4S ] cluster acquired by wild-type FNR under the same conditions . [19261852]
  • In the presence of oxygen , the cluster disintegrates , and the protein no longer specifically binds DNA2 ~ Thus , FNR provides a clear example in which a reactive iron-sulfur cluster is used to sense concentrations of the destabilizing agent , oxygen . [8871401]
  • FNR senses the presence of oxygen by disassembly of its oxygen-sensitive iron-sulfur cluster , converting the protein to a non ¬ DNA-binding monomer ( 13 ) . [21252224]
  • FNR senses oxygen via an N-terminal iron -- sulfur cluster . [17164287]
  • Thus , our work provides insight into the mechanism of the iron -- sulfur cluster rearrangements that switch FNR between active and inactive forms and implies that residues equivalent to position 24 in E. coli FNR , inter alia , play a key role in determining the sensitivity of the switch , thereby matching FNR activity to a range of O2 concentrations that require a response in the environmental niche inhabited by the bacterium . [19261852]
  • In vivo transcription experiments indicate that other amino acids with bulky side chains at position 24 also protect the FNR iron -- sulfur cluster . [19261852]
  • These data support the proposal that a bulky amino acid side chain at position 24 protects the FNR iron -- sulfur cluster from O2 and also suggest that enhanced FNR activity is detrimental during aerobic growth of E. coli . [19261852]

  • Cysteine cluster in FNR : Homology with metal-binding proteins The third functionally important domain in FNR is represented by a cluster of cysteine residues close to the N-terminus ( Fig. 1 ) . [1854188]
  • The N-terminal cysteine cluster of FNR shows homology to metal-binding domains of the type of metal proteins ( X = any amino acid ) ( Berg 1986 ) . [1854188]
  • However , FNR and FNR-like sensor proteins contain an N-terminal extension with three or four cysteine residues , three of which are part of a cluster of four conserved and essential cycteine residues in the protein w67 -- 69,71 x . [9230919]

  • YeiL also lacks the cysteine-rich N-terminal extension that provides three of the four ligands for the sensory iron -- sulphur cluster of FNR . [11101674]

  • NO reacts anaerobically with the Fe ± S cluster of puri ® ed FNR , generating spectral changes consistent with formation of a dinitrosyl-iron ± cysteine complex . [12093725]
  • FNR possesses a cysteine cluster to which iron ( Fe ( H ) ) binds only in the active form [ 2,6 ] . [8119409]
  • Iron and sulfide analyses and CD spectra of FNR preparations derived from reconstitution of a cluster into apoprotein also supports this cluster assignment ( 4 ) . [9177174]
  • The results showing up to three NO per Fe ± S cluster to complete the overall reaction in FNR suggest a multistep process . [12093725]
  • The FNR protein , previously suggested to contain an Fe ion , is now known to carry a FeS cluster Žpresumably 4Fe4S . [9230919]
  • By oxidation of the FeS cluster , FNR is converted to the inactive state in a reversible process . [9230919]
  • Such a redox reaction would be conceivable for a supposed Cys4 · Fe rubredoxin-type cluster or an Fe-S center in FNR . [8588737]
  • Cysteine/Histidine cluster in FNR and ( supposed ) metal proteins . [1854188]
  • Since the two cluster types of FNR utilize the same four cysteinyl ligands ( 4 ) , studies of FNR provide an unusual opportunity to compare the properties of two types of Fe-S clusters within the same protein environment . [14730984]
  • Because IscR contained a series of Cys residues , we reasoned that it might contain a Fe-S cluster ; therefore , the protein was purified under anaerobic conditions by using the overexpression scheme previously shown to allow isolation of the FNR protein , which contains an oxygen-sensitive Fe-S cluster ( 25 ) . [11742080]
  • It is important to recall that we tested IscR , a transcriptional regulator with an oxygen sensitive Fe-S cluster , an oxygen-resistant variant of FNR , another transcriptional regulator , and the Nuo and Sdh complexes that both contain buried oxygen resistant Fe-S clusters . [25430730]

  • Note that bacteria having multiple FNR homologues usually contain a typical FNR with a E -- SR motif and at least one other homulogue with a PE -- SR motif . [11407111]
  • These observations suggested that a fraction of purified FNR contains an internal disulphide bridge or at least one cysteine residue that is modified by a substituent that can be removed reductively . [8497198]
  • However , the PE -- SR motif allows FLP and FIpA to recognize FLP ( CCTGA ) and FNR ( TTGAT ) sites , indicating that residues outside the recognition motifs and recognition helices can profoundly affect the recognition specificities of this type of regulator . [11407111]
  • It has been suggested that side chains of these residues make interactions with the T-A and G-C base pairs at positions 1 and 3 of the TTGAT motif of the FNR box . [7747934]
  • At the sensory level , the basic structural fold has been adapted in FNR and FLP by the acquisition in the N-terminal region of different combinations of cysteine or other residues , which bestow oxygen/redox sensing mechanisms that are poised according to the oxidative stress thresholds affecting the metabolism of specific bacteria . [11407111]
  • These observations suggest that the cysteine residues participate in iron-binding and that the interconversion of the ` aerobic ' and ` anaerobic ' species of FNR is a redox reaction with a protein-bound metal ion as the redox-sensitive site ( Fig. 3 ) . [1957353]
  • Role of cysteine residues and iron for 02-sensing by FNR In bacteria two forms of FNR , an aerobic and an anaerobic , can be differentiated ( Trageser & Unden 1989 ) . [1854188]
  • The existence of an FNR-like protein having only two cysteine residues , in an organism that probably lacks iron , led to the speculation that FLP might operate the same transcriptional switch as FNR but at a later stage in the signal transduction pathway , thus by-passing the need for iron . [11407111]
  • Indeed , the properties of FNR ( 27 , confirm that a high iron content is compatible with the presence of an intramolecular disulphide ( Table 1 , Fig. 1 ) and this implies that residues other than cysteine serve as Ngands for iron . [8497198]
  • The FNR protein exists in two forms separable by non-reducing SOS-PAGE , and in studies with altered FNR proteins containing single substitutions at each of the five cysteine residues it was concluded that the fastermigrating form ( FNR ( 27 ) ) , possesses an intramolecular disulphide bond linking C122 to one of the cysteines near the Mterminus . [8497198]
  • The presence of the two forms of FNR was investigated in at least two independent preparations of five mutant proteins , each containing a substitution in one of the five cysteine residues , together with studies on their ability to bind iron and the reactivity of their suiphydryi groups ( Table 1 ; Fig. 1 ) . [8497198]
  • Since this could involve disulphide formation or some other modification which might be related to redox-sensing , five FNR proteins with single substitutions In each of the cysteine residues were purified and characterized with respect to the presence of the two forms , the relationship between the iron and reactive sulphydryl contents , and the ability to interact with target DNA . [8497198]
  • It was hoped that a clear link between iron-binding and specific sulphydryl ligands would emerge from studies with FNR proteins containing single substitutions at each of the five cysteine residues . [8497198]
  • Furthermore , the cysteinyl ligands of apo-FNR are sufficiently reactive to generate intramolecular disulfide bonds between Cys122 and one of the Nterminal cysteine residues ( Green et al. , 1993 ) , with the production of an oxidized or disulfide form of apo-FNR , designated [ 2SH , S-S ] in Fig. 2 . [11407111]
  • Of the five cysteine residues in FNR , Cys-122 appears to be the most important in that it is absolutely required for disulphide bond formation , iron-binding and covalent modification ( Green et al. 1993 ) . [7747934]
  • Such a disulphide bridge might have been expected to affect the electrophoretic behaviour of all but two of the cysteine-substituted FNR proteins ( i.e. the two in which the residues participating in bridge formation are replaced ) , rather than all but one ( FNR-385 , C122A ) . [8497198]
  • Footprint studies indicated that FNR proteins lacking essential cysteine residues are impaired in their ability to protect FNR sites in the ndh promoter . [8497198]
  • In the proteins from closely related bacteria , > 74 % of the amino acids are identical to those of FNR , and each of the five cysteine residues of FNR is conserved ( Table 3 ) . [8588737]

  • Disulphide bonding might also play a role in regulating the function of the FNR protein , since an / V-terminal segment containing three cysteine residues is essential for activating the target frd operon encoding fumarate reductase , an enzyme for anaerobic respiration ( Spiro and Guest , 1988 ) . [2201868]
  • Site-directed mutagenesis has demonstrated that the internal cysteine , and three of the four cysteines in the N-terminal cluster are essential for the normal function of FNR ( Spiro & Guest 1988 ; Sharrocks et al. 1990 ) . [7747934]
  • By the N-terminal extension and a further essential cysteine residue close to the center ( Cys122 ) , FNR and FNR homologs are clearly differentiated from CRP . [8588737]
  • It differs from CRP in being monomeric , in possessing a cysteine ~ rich amino-terminal segment that contains three of the four essential cysteine residues in FNR , and in binding equimolar amounts of iron4 ,6 , t2 . [1957353]
  • FNR carries an N-terminal extension of 29 amino acid residues containing four cysteine residues , three of which are essential ( Melville and Gunsalus 1990 ; Sharrocks et al. 1990 ) . [8588737]
  • FNR is predicted to contain ail of the structural elements of CRP but it differs from CRP in being monomeric rather than dimeric , containing up to one atom of iron per monomer , and having an A / - terminal extension that includes three of the four essential cysteine residues ( Green ef ai , 1991 ; Sharrocks ef ai , 1990 ; Melville and Gunsalus , 1990 ) . [8065261]

  • The speciﬁc amount of ﬂuorescence per FNR protein showed a linear relationship to the number of accessible Cys residues ( Fig. 2 ) . [18055593]
  • The speciﬁc labeling varied by a factor of approximately 5 when FNR with one and ﬁve accessible Cys residues was labeled , conﬁrming that by this method up to ﬁve Cys residues per FNR become labeled . [18055593]
  • Up to ﬁve Cys residues per FNR become labeled by mBBr , and the number of reactive residues varies between one and two and about four Cys residues in vivo per FNR depending on the presence of O2 . [18055593]
  • Before the shift , about 20 % of the Cys residues ( corresponding to about one labeled Cys residue/FNR ) were accessible to mBBr . [18055593]
  • In particular , there were no signals equivalent to FNR labeled at only one or three Cys residues which would be characteristic for the presence of two or one intramolecular disulﬁde bonds . [18055593]
  • mBBr binding was quantitatively calibrated using FNR with one , two , three , and ﬁve Cys residues in the thiol state . [18055593]
  • In this way , FNR with one , two , three , or ﬁve Cys residues in the thiol state was available , which then reacted with mBBr . [18055593]
  • FNR with an Mr of 32,000 is presumably labeled at three ( or two ) Cys residues by AMS . [18055593]
  • Again , there were no signiﬁcant signals with masses corresponding to that of unlabeled FNR or to the masses of forms of FNR with only one , two , or three alkylated Cys residues . [18055593]
  • Alkylation of FNR in aerobic bacteria and counting the labeled residues by mass spectrometry showed a form of FNR with ﬁve accessible Cys residues , corresponding to apoFNR with all Cys residues in the thiol state . [18055593]
  • Labeling of FNR in vivo in aerobic bacteria with NEM showed indeed the theoretical value of ﬁve accessible residues predicted for apoFNR . [18055593]
  • ApoFNR can be differentiated from FNR containing Fe-S clusters by measuring the accessibility of the Cys residues ( 1 ) . [18055593]
  • Labeling reagents like mBBr which selectively label accessible Cys residues without removing the labile FeS cluster allowed identiﬁcation of apoFNR and differentiation from FeS-containing FNR in vivo . [18055593]

  • Hence CRP makes active contacts via AR1 and AR2 , whereas FNR uses an extended AR 1 contact and AR3 . [11407111]
  • In this context , there is a core motif ( TTGAT ) for a potential FNR half-site at about -55 in the putative ttdABpromoter region ( Nesin et al. , 1987 ) , and an analogous CRP half-site motif ( GTGTA ) at - 130 . [8371115]
  • In FNR , the region analogous to CRP-AR3 , FNR-AR3 , appears to have a similar transcription-activation function , as amino acid substitutions within this region decrease transcription-activation of two class II promoters ( Fig. 2 ) ( West et al. , 1993 ; Bell and Busby , 1994 ) . [11115116]
  • FNR-AR1 includes not only the region analogous to CRP-AR1 ( referred to as the 181 ± 191 loop in FNR ) , but also two other surfaceexposed patches ( amino acids 71 ± 75 and 116 ± 121 ) . [11115116]
  • Additionally , some of the fnr mutations that alter oxygen regulation are located at positions in FNR analogous to those found in the L-roll region and the dimerization helix of CAP [ 15 ] . [9990723]
  • To screen for variant with further enhanced activity , we introduced D154A substitution which has been demonstrated to enhance dimerization between two FNR monomers in the presence of oxygen . [22326866]
  • Several observations indicate that although a large portion of the AR1 surface is involved in FNR II mediated downregulation , the protein -- protein interactions that are involved are speciﬁc and easily perturbed . [9767578]

[9582376]
  • The C-terminal domain of s70 ( sCTD ) contains a putative helix-turn-helix motif ( region 4.2 , residues 570 to 613 ) which recognizes the 235 promoter element ( 15 ) and some of the transcription activators that bind near the 235 region , including l cI , PhoB , Ada , cyclic AMP ( cAMP ) receptor protein ( CAP ) -- activating region-3 ( AR3 ) , FNR , and phage Mu Mor proteins ( 1 , 21 , 23 -- 25 ) . [10572130]

  • Characterization of the dimerization domain in the FNR transcription factor . [15547274, 15375149, 17293415]
  • FNR is believed to contain a redox/02-sensitive element for detecting the anaerobic state . [8577745]
  • FNR is believed to contain a redox / 02-sensitive domain that senses the anaerobic state and converts the protein into an active conformation for DNA-binding ( 5 , 6 ) . [8577745]
  • Thus it would seem that FNR activation may be controlled by a redox-sensitive iron cofactor in the iron-FNR-DNA complex which senses and responds to the redox state of the celt . [8497198]
  • Thus it has been proposed that the A / - terminal cysteine cluster forms an iron-binding redox-sensing-domain and that FNR activation involves an allosteric transition initiated by a redox-sensitive iron cofactor ( Green ef ai , 1991 ; Green and Guest , 1993a , b ) . [8065261]

  • For example , Paracoccus denitrificans has two paralogous FNR-like proteins , FnrP and NNR , which are each predicted to recognize FNR sites by the presence of E -- SR motifs in their DNA-recognition helices ( Fig. 4b ) and by the presence of potential FNR sites in FnrP - and NNR-dependent promoters . [11407111]
  • Based on these predictions , CRP and FNR homologues have been classified according to the amino-acid-sequence motifs in their putative DNA-recognition helices , where those containing the FNR motif ( E -- SR ) are regarded as FNR-like proteins and those containing the CRP motif ( RE -- R ) are regarded as CRP-like proteins ( Spiro , 1994 ) . [11407111]
  • Within the FNR family of regulators , we observed a correlation of two specificity-determining amino acids and contacting bases in corresponding DNA-recognition motif . [16261196]
  • These contacts were prevented by FNR binding to the secondary site , leading to inhibition of open complex formation and repression of ndh transcription . [8065261]
  • Anaerobic ndh repression may thus involve the binding of two pairs of FNR mono-mers upstream of the - 3 5 region , which prevents essentiai RNA poiymerase-DNA contacts in the upstream region as well as inhibiting RNA piolymer-ase function by direct FNR interaction . [8065261]
  • It would thus appear that FNR mediates repression by altering the formation of DNA-RNA polymerase contacts in the - 5 8 to - 1 3 2 region and through inhibitory FNR-RNA polymerase contacts , rather than by directly blocking RNA polymerase binding at the promoter -LCB- promoter occlusion ) . [8065261]
  • The effects of mutations in the activator proteins and DNase footprinting suggest that the C-terminal domain of the alpha subunit of RNA polymerase may contact both CAP and FNR and simultaneously come close to the DNA between the two activators . [10715008]
  • Arr positioned at -83 would be on the same face of the DNA helix as FNR at -41.5 and thus both regulators could contact RNA polymerase to activate transcription synergistically . [9308170]
  • Based on a comparison with the cAMP receptor protein ( CRP ) and its recognition sequence on the DNA , Spiro and Guest ( 1990 ) have proposed that a glutamic acid residue in the DNA-binding domain of FNR makes an important contact with the GC base pair in the DNA sequence . [7934836]
  • FNR differs from CRP in three amino acid residues ( Val-208 , Ser-212 and Gly-216 in FNR ) which are known to be critical for specific binding of CRP to DNA . [1854188]
  • As originally pointed out by Guest and co-workers ( Shaw et al. , 1983 ) , FNR is structurally similar to CAP , and the substitution of three amino acid residues in its DNA-binding domain is sufficient to allow anaerobic recognition of the CAP site in the lac promoter by the altered FNR protein ( Spiro and Guest , 1987b ) . [2677602]
  • Mutagenesis studies with FNR ( Spiro and Guest , 1987 ; Spiro et al. , 1990 ) have indicated that as in CRP , the amino acid residues contacting the FNR target site are located in the putative DNA-recognition helix ( c ~ F ) of FNR ( Plate 3 ) . [11407111]
  • Nevertheless , FLP is regarded as an FNR homologue because of its likely DNA-binding specificity and its possession of two conserved cysteine residues ( Irvine & Guest , 1993 ; see below ) . [7747934]
  • The core interactions between the Glu ( position 2 ) and Arg ( position 6 ) residues and the conserved C-G and T-A base pairs at the FNR , FLP and CRP DNA-binding sites , arc indicated . [11407111]
  • However , because the core motif and two residues in the DNA-binding motif ( E -- R ; Glu 184 an Arg188 ) are conserved relative to CRP and FNR , it is predicted that FLP will make the same contacts with its target , as shown in Fig. 4a . [11407111]
  • However , FIpA and FIpB were designated FNR-like because : they are more similar to FNR than CRP when conservative amino acid substitutions are included in the comparison ; they retain the FNR-like DNA-recognition motif ( see below ) and lack the amino acid residues required for cAMP-binding ; and they retain one N-terminal cysteine residue ( Cysl5 ) and a single internal residue ( Cys112 ) corresponding to two of the four essential cysteine residues of FNR ( Plate 3a ; Gostick et al. , 1999 ) . [11407111]
  • 21 % identical to CRP and FNR , and it shares many features with the Lactococcus lactis proteins , including an FNR-like DNA-recognition helix ( even though it does not bind to the canonical FNR site , see below ) and only two cysteine residues ( Plate 3a ) . [11407111]
  • Based on sequence homology with CRP ( 8 ) , FNR consists of a C-terminal DNA-binding domain , which recognizes specific sequences within FNR-controlled promoters ( 9 ) , and an Nterminal sensory-domain containing 5 cysteine residues , 4 of which , Cys-20 , 23 , 29 , and 122 , but not Cys-16 , are essential for function ( 10 , 11 ) . [19261852]
  • , two Synechocystis species ; NtcA Sy3 , Svnechococcus species ; NtcA Sy7 , Synechococcus species ; PrfA Li , Listeria ivanovii ; PflA Lm , Listeria mono ~ wtogenes ; PtrA Sy , ~ vnechococcus species ; Vfr Pa , Pseudomonas aeruk , inosa ; Ycf Pp , Porphyra purpurea : YeiL Ec , Escherichia coli ( 3 ) have a predicted DNA-binding specificity corresponding to that of FNR rather than CRP ; ( 4 ) fail to respond to cAMP ; ( 5 ) respond to oxygen limitation ; and ( 6 ) retain all or most of the characteristic ` cysteine signature ' of FNR , which comprises three essential N-terminal cysteine residues and a fourth essential cysteine within the [ 3-roll . [11407111]

  • The G residue has been proposed to form an important contact with a glutamic acid residue in the helix-turn-helix DNA-binding domain of the FNR protein ( Belief a / . [7934836]
  • The DNA-binding domain The DNA-binding domain of the E. coli FNR protein is well defined , both from genetic studies and on the basis of its similarity to the helix-turn-helix units of related DNA-binding proteins . [7747934]
  • From the sequence it is further predicted that FNR contains a DNA-binding domain with a helix-turn-helix motif and a nucleotide-binding domain . [1957353]
  • Three characteristic regions of homology are present , a helix-turn-helix DNA-binding motif at the C-terminus ( residues 196 to 219 in FNR ) , a nucleotide cofactor binding domain ( residues 54 to 104 in FNR ) and a cysteine cluster ( residues 16 to 29 in FNR ) . [1854188]
  • The C-terminal domain of FNR is involved in sitespeci cents c DNA-binding via a putative helix-turn-helix motif ( residues 195 ^ 215 ) . [9990723]
  • The fourth subgroup within the major FNR group is designated DNR/FLP to denote a distinct group of regulators having sensory functions as well as potential FNR-like DNA-binding activities . [11407111]
  • The DNA-binding domains are the most highly conserved regions of the FNR family of proteins as illustrated in Fig. 3 . [7747934]
  • CRP DNA-binding domains are aligned with the closely related P.aeruginosa DNR and the distantly related E.coli FNR . [17068078]
  • Each is predicted to have the same , or a very similar , DNA-binding specificity as that of FNR , as judged by the structures of their DNA-binding domains . [7747934]
  • One feature used in classifying the FLP of Lactobacillus casei as an FNR homologue was the presence of the FNR-like DNA-binding motif ( E -- SR ) in the putative recognition helix , c ~ r ( Plate 3a ) . [11407111]
  • Further mutagenic and structural studies will be needed to support this prediction and to identify other residues that contact DNA and define the DNA-binding specificity of FLE A major difference that might explain the divergent DNA-binding specificities of FNR and FLP is the presence of proline as the first residue of the DNA-recognition helix in FLP ( Fig. 4 ) . [11407111]
  • ( a ) The DNA-recognition helices of CRP , FNR and FLP are shown in hall-helical wheel format numbered from the first residue of the helix . [11407111]
  • The DNA-recognition helix of FNR possesses no equivalent to Arg180 of CRP ; instead , a serine residue ( Ser212 ) makes contact with the first T-A pair of the FNR-site ( Fig. 4a ) . [11407111]
  • These are different in each case but they represent major structural features such as the sensory-domain ( β-roll ) and dimer-interface ( α ) of CRP C and the DNA-recognition helix ( α ) of FNR . [11101674]
  • For the regions of FNR and FixK corresponding to the DNA-binding domain of CRP , a helix-turn-helix structure similar to that of CRP can be modelled ( Shaw et al. 1983 ; Cherfils et al. 1989 ) . [1854188]

  • Since a symmetrical binding motif is typical of dimeric proteins , this similarity suggested that FNR might also be dimeric . [9990723]
  • All FNR proteins contain NAD ( P ) and FAD binding sites and it is here where the greatest sequence similarity among family members is seen . [7821669]

  • A analysis showed that YeiL is more closely related to members of the CRP -- FNR family ( 16 -- 22 % identical , 42 -- 45 % similar ) than to other known proteins . [11101674]
  • Sequence comparisons with representative members of each subgroup of the CRP -- FNR family showed that YeiL is : 22 % identical ( 42 % similar ) to the FNR of E. coli ; 19 % identical ( 45 % similar ) to the FLP of L. casei ; 19 % identical ( 44 % similar ) to the FixK of Rhizobium meliloti ; and 17 % identical ( 45 % similar ) to the CRP of E. coli . [11101674]
  • A recent paper by Elvers et al. [ 52 ] describes a new nitrosative stress-responsive regulon in e-proteobacterium C. jejuni regulated by a member of the CRP/FNR family . [16261196]
  • The complete genome of Escherichia coli ( Blattner et al. , 1997 ) was recently shown to encode a third member of the CRP -- FNR family ( YeiL ) when searched with a sequence proﬁle derived from a multiple alignment of ﬁve members of the family : CRP and FNR from E. coli ; FLP from L. casei ; and FlpA and FlpB from Lactococcus lactis ( Gostick et al. , 1999 ) . [11101674]
  • A phylogenetic tree derived from 38 members of the CRP -- FNR family indicated that YeiL is a distant relative of the CRP group ( Gostick et al. , 1999 ) . [11101674]
  • Synopsis Results HcpR : Recognition Motifs and Core Regulon A member of the CRP/FNR family of transcription factors , HcpR has been initially identiﬁed as the regulator of the hcp gene encoding the hybrid cluster protein and the frdX encoding a ferredoxin-like protein in the Desulfovibrio species , anaerobic metal-reducing d-proteobacteria [ 33 ] . [16261196]
  • Site-directed deletion suggests that the extr tqL , ure 3 Schematic representations of the oxygen/redox-sensing switches operated by three members of the CRP-FNR super family of transcription factors . [11407111]
  • Various transcription factors of the FNR family have been described as NO-sensing regulators of denitriﬁcation : DNR in Pseudomonas species , NNR in Paracoccus denitriﬁcans , and NnrR in Rhodobacter sphaeroides and Bradyrhizobium japonicum [ 18 ] . [16261196]
  • Its hyphenated dyad symmetry resembles that of the binding sites for other regulators with helix-turn-helix motifs ( e.g , CRP and FNR ) but it differs from the known sites for other members of the GntR family which exhibit uninterrupted dyad symmetry , i.e. GntR -LCB- ATACnGTATACAAGTAT : Fujita and Miwa , 1989 ) and HutCpp -LCB- TTGJAATAtAc ; Hu et ai . [7783622]
  • The FNR family includes such diverse proteins as mammalian nitric oxide synthase and cytochrome ( cyt ) b , reductase , spinach FNR and bacterial toluate and benzoate dioxygenases . [7821669]
  • Invariant residues defining a fingerprint for the FAD and NAD domains in proteins belonging to the FNR family [ 30,31 ] are conserved in the E. coli HCR , as indicated in Fig. 2 . [10651802]
  • The DNA-binding domains are the most highly conserved regions of the FNR family of proteins as illustrated in Fig. 3 . [7747934]
  • All FNR proteins contain NAD ( P ) and FAD binding sites and it is here where the greatest sequence similarity among family members is seen . [7821669]
  • These enzymes are members of the ferredoxin-NADP1 reductase ( FNR ) family and they contain a FNR-like domain consisting of a FMN ( FAD ) - and a NAD ( P ) - binding region ( 57 ) . [9748275]
  • PDR belongs to the ferredoxin ± NADP reductase ( FNR ) family of flavoproteins + [ 29,30 ] . [10651802]
  • In addition the yeast and the E. coli proteins contain a C-terminal domain homologous to the ferredoxin NAr ) P + reductase ( FNR ) family , FNR . [7821669]
  • The E. coli globin-like protein HMP [ 6 ] is a soluble protein with two structural domains : the Nterminal portion shows striking similarity to VGB and leghaemoglobin , whilst the C-terminal portion is related to proteins in the ferredoxin-NADP + reductase ( FNR ) family [ 7 ] . [7875569]
  • [ 9 ] Green , J. , Scott , C. and Guest , J.R. ( 2001 ) Functional versatility in CRP-FNR family of transcription factors : FNR and FLP . [14612240]
  • Introduction The FNR protein of Escherichia coli is an oxygen-respon-sive member of the structurally related CRP/FNR family of transcription regulators ( Guest et al. , 1996 ) . [9767578]
  • The L. casei FLP protein groups with the CRP rather than the FNR family . [7747934]
  • Keywords : CRP -- FNR protein superfamily , iron -- sulphur proteins , transcriptional regulation , nitrogen starvation , stationary phase INTRODUCTION The CRP -- FNR family of transcription regulators contains at least 70 members that respond to a variety of metabolic and environmental signals to control a diverse range of physiological functions in an equally diverse range of bacteria ( Spiro , 1994 ; Guest et al. , 1996 ; Vollack et al. , 1999 ) . [11101674]
  • DISCUSSION The yeiL gene of E. coli was predicted to encode a new and distinct member of the CRP -- FNR family of transcriptional regulators that might have an iron -- sulphur centre and a reversible intra - or inter-molecular disulphide bond . [11101674]
  • FNR is predicted to contain all the structural elements of CRP , and both regulators constitute a family of transcriptional regulators . [8588737]
  • Spiro , S. ( 1994 ) The FNR family of transcription regulators . [11407111]
  • The FNR family of transcriptional regulators . [11101674]
  • [ 3 ] Spiro , S. ( 1994 ) The FNR family of transcriptional regulators . [9990723]
  • The FNR protein is highly homologous to CAP ( 23 , 24 ) . [2403539]
  • The occurrence of multiple protein -- protein contacts between a transcriptional regulator and RNAP has been most thoroughly characterized in the case of catabolite activator protein ( CAP , CAP/FNR family ) . [15255893]
  • The only family members that diverge flom this arrangement are the FNR proteins of Bacillus suhtilis and Bacillus lichenifbnnis , where the sensory domains are located primarily at the C-termini ( Cruz-Ramos et al. , 1995 ; Klinger et al. , 1998 ) . [11407111]
  • However , there may be subtle differences in the DNA-binding specificities in at least some members of the FNR family ( Galimand et al. 1991 ; Sawers 1991 ; Green et al. 1992 ) . [7747934]
  • The DNR/NNR and NnrR proteins cluster phylogenetically in separate subgroups , separately from other family members including FNR , a global regulator of anaerobiosis in facultative anaerobic bacteria [ 20 ] . [16261196]
  • Some members of this family , like FNR itself , appear to function as sensors of oxygen availability , whereas others do not . [7747934]
  • The conserved motif found in SsuE suggests that the mechanism of flavin reduction may be similar to other members of the FNR family . [17289450]
  • Despite being structurally very similar , members of the FNR family have disparate regulatory roles . [7747934]
  • It is of interest to examine the sequence alignment of FNR , HlyX and BTR ( Fig. 3 ) in search of lea bacterium belonging to the family Pasteurellaceae an + . [7747934]
  • However , Gln-84 of FNR is replaced by serine in both HlyX and BTR , but in no other member of this family ( Fig. 3 ) . [7747934]
  • Recently , a general flavin reductase , Fre , was also shown to belong to the FNR family based on the mechanism of flavin reduction [ 26 ] . [17289450]
  • However , an amino acid sequence ( RXXS ) conserved within the spinach ferredoxin-NADP + reductase family of enzymes ( FNR family ) has also been identified in SsuE [ 18 ] . [17289450]
  • As mentioned , the conserved RXXS sequence found in the FNR family has also been identified in SsuE [ 18 ] . [17289450]

[18158297]
  • The transcriptional start sites and translational-initiation sites ( bold ) , the -35 and -10 hexamers of putative promoters ( boxed ) , alternative hexamers for P2 , , , A ( dashed overlined ) , ribosome binding sites ( RBS ) , and potential binding sites for FNR ( black box ) , CRP ( bold overlined ) , ArcA ( underlined ) and Fis ( dashed underlined ) , are shown for ( a ) acnA ( co-ordinates 701-1250 ; Prodromou et a / . [9421904, 9421904]
  • Transcription depends upon CRP , the anaerobically triggered transcription activator FNR , the glyoxylate shunt repressor IclR and its activator FadR , and several enzymes involved in acetate-metabolism . [12923087]
  • We also have found that the timing and/or magnitude of this induction depends , in part , on the carbon regulator cyclic AMP ( cAMP ) receptor protein ( CRP ) , the oxygen regulator FNR , the glyoxylate shunt repressor IclR and its activator FadR , and several enzymes involved in acetate-metabolism . [10894724]
  • These seemingly include direct interactions by CRP and FNR to activate transcription initiation and indirect effects by acetate metabolic enzymes and transcription factors that control carbon ﬂux . [10894724]
  • Our set of 11 global regulators are transcription factors involved in carbon degradation ( mlc and lrp ) , redox status sensing ( arcA , narL and FNR ) , ion-transport regulation ( fur ) , environmental sensors ( cspA and CRP ) , a regulator of structural proteins ( hns ) and two general enhancers ( IHF and FIS ) . [12582243]
  • Thus the global regulators are proteins that control responses to changing food levels and carbon degradation ( mlc , lrp , CRP ) and transcription factors that respond to changes in redox status or ion levels of the cell ( arcA , narL , FNR , fur ) . [12582243]
  • Our study showed that perturbation of the global regulator FNR and PurR function as well as increase in purine nucleotide availability , could affect the oxidative damage cell-death pathway initiated by topoisomerase cleavage complex . [22152010]

Kiley a ; * , Helmut Beinert b a Department of Biomolecular Chemistry , 574 Medical Science Center , 1300 University Avenue , University of Wisconsin Medical School , Madison , WI 53706 , USA b Institute for Enzyme Research , Graduate School , and Department of Biochemistry , University of Wisconsin-Madison , Madison , WI 53706 , USA Received 2 June 1998 ; received in revised form 7 September 1998 ; accepted 7 September 1998 Abstract FNR is a global regulator that controls transcription of genes whose functions facilitate adaptation to growth under O2 limiting conditions . [16857675]
  • Other Gram-negative bacteria In a number of other species of Gram-negative bacteria there is indirect evidence for the presence of FNR homologues , usually from the observation of FNR boxes in the upstream regions of genes involved in denitrification ( Fig. 2 ) . [7747934]
  • Vollack , K.U. , Hartig , E. , Korner , H. and Zumft , W.G. ( 1999 ) Multiple transcription factors of the FNR family in denitrifying Pxeudotnona , s stut ; eri : characterization of fourfi ~ r-like genes , regulatory responses and cognate metabolic-processes . [11407111]
  • Transcription of a further group of genes , including yeaR , yoaG , yibH , and yibI encoding proteins of unknown function , is partially FNR-dependent and strongly induced by nitrate but also strongly induced by nitrite in an FNR mutant , suggesting that multiple regulatory circuits regulate the response of these genes to nitrate and nitrite . [16377617]
  • Dominy CN , Deane SM , Rawlings DE ( 1997 ) A geographically widespread plasmid from Thiobacillus ferrooxidans has genes for ferredoxin - , FNR - , prismane - and NADH-oxidoreductase-like proteins which are also located on the chromosome . [16261196]
  • Green , J. , Sharrocks , A.D. , MacInnes , J.I. , and Guest , J.R. ( 1992 ) Puriﬁcation of HlyX , a potential regulator of haemo-lysin synthesis , and properties of HlyX : FNR hybrids . [9767578]
  • Green , J. , and Baldwin , M.L. ( 1997a ) HlyX , the FNR homologue of Actinobacillus pleuropneumoniae , is a [ 4Fe-4S ] - containing oxygen-responsive transcription regulator that anaerobically activates FNR-dependent Class I promoters via an enhanced AR1 contact . [9767578]
  • To test if tandem construct ( FNRD154A ) 2 also activates other FNR dependent promoters under aerobic conditions , we measured b-gal activity of FNR activated PnarG-lacZ , PdmsA-lacZ , and FNR repressed Pndh-lacZ ( Fig. 2 ) . [22326866]
  • The recent description of mutant proteins ( FNR * ) that are active under aerobic growth conditions is a potentially important development ~ 6 . [1957353]
  • The protective effect of Δfnr mutation was greater under low oxygen conditions The genes suppressed by FNR directly or indirectly via the sRNA FnrS [ 26,27 ] include many aerobic metabolic genes as well as genes involved in removal of reactive-oxygen-species such as katE , sodA and sodB [ 16 ] . [22152010]
  • The product of the aadR gene is structurally related to FNR , and is proposed to be involved in regulating the biosynthesis of benzoate-CoA ligase and aromatic acid-CoA ligase II , which are required for benzoate and 4-hydroxybenzoate-catabolism respectively ( Dispensa et al. 1992 ) . [7747934]
  • The identification of an FNR box in the regulatory region of the lux regulon supports the notion that FNR is involved in the regulation of luminescence ( Fig. 2 ; U. Winkler , personal communication ) . [7747934]
  • The genetic evidence suggests that three other residues of FNR are involved in positive control : Ile-81 , Thr-82 , Asp ¬ 86 and Glu-87 . [7747934]

[15546870]

  • Key words FNR · Anaerobic gene regulation · Oxygen · Facultative anaerobic metabolism · Anaerobic-respiration Biological role of facultative anaerobic metabolism Facultatively anaerobic metabolism is wide-spread among bacteria and archaea , including purple phototrophic ( pro-teo - ) and gram-positive bacteria and halophilic or thermophilic archaea ( see review by Unden et al. 1994 ) . [8588737]
  • Disulphide bonding might also play a role in regulating the function of the FNR protein , since an / V-terminal segment containing three cysteine residues is essential for activating the target frd operon encoding fumarate reductase , an enzyme for anaerobic-respiration ( Spiro and Guest , 1988 ) . [2201868]
  • The isolation of mutants with pleiotropic defects in anaerobic-respiration led to the identification of the fnr gene , also known as nirA or nirR ( Lambden and Guest , 1976 ; Newman and Cole , 1978 ; Chippaux et al. , 1978 ) encoding a 28000 Dalton polypeptide , FNR ( Shaw and Guest , 1982a , b ) , which is homologous to the catabolite gene activator protein , CAP ( Shaw et al. , 1983 ) . [2677602]
  • The regulators of anaerobic-respiration ( FNR , fumarate-nitrate-regulator ) and of nitrogen-fixation in Klebsiella ( NifA/NifL ) are known ( Lambden & Guest 1976 ; Newman & Cole 1978 ; Chippaux et al. 1978 ; Filser et al. 1983 ) . [1854188]
  • Those from Shewanella putrefaciens , Pseudomonas aeruginosa , Pseudomonas stutzeri and Rhodopseudomonas palustris are functionally similar to FNR in that they regulate anaerobic-respiration or carbon metabolism . [7747934]
  • Finally , with the emergence of aerobic metabolism , all the operators involved in anaerobic-respiration would eventually have to have been endowed with a site for the FNR regulatory protein . [3035558]
  • It is tempting to speculate that other members of the purple nonsulphur bacteria may have FNR homologues , which are involved not in the regulation-of-photosynthesis , but in other aspects of anaerobic metabolism such as nitrate respiration and degradation of aromatic compounds . [7747934]

  • When the terminal electron acceptor , O2 , is no longer available , FNR represses the synthesis of enzymes involved in aerobic-respiration and increases the synth-esis of enzymes required for anaerobic-respiration . [11115116]
  • FNR also represses synthesis of enzymes required for aerobic-respiration , such as NADH dehydrogenase II . [9990723]
  • Most genes involved in an-aerobic-respiration fall into group I , which are upregulated by FNR anaerobically . [15659690]
  • FNR and ArcA are involved in sensing the redox status of the cell to regulate genes involved in respiration under aerobic and anaerobic conditions . [12582243]
  • Under the same conditions FNR represses some of the genes of aerobic-respiration . [1854188]
  • The anaerobic repression of ndhH and the genes of th terminal oxidases cyo ( and cyd ) indicates that FNR also functions for some genes as a repressor of aerobic-respiration during anoxia . [1854188]
  • The transcription factor FNR is known to activate genes involved with anaerobic metabolism while ArcB governs the expression of aerobic-respiration-related genes ( Salmon et al. , 2003 ; Shalel-Levanon et al. , 2005 ) . [23563322]

[18055593]
  • FNR is a CRP homologue and regulates genes during anaerobic growth . [15520470]
  • Collectively , our results provide insight into the mechanism by which FNR negatively regulates genes such as sodA , sodB , cydDC , and metE , thereby demonstrating that adaptation to anaerobic growth involves the action of a small regulatory RNA . [20075074]
  • Furthermore , the anaerobic transcription of fnrS was abolished in a fnr strain , thus demonstrating that the global regulatory protein FNR induces FnrS transcription in response to anoxic growth conditions . [20075074]
  • Under aerobic growth conditions , proteolysis decreases FNR protein levels ( 12 , 38 ) , while under anaerobic conditions , FNR represses its own transcription ( 24 , 41 , 44 , 47 , 54 ) . [17293415]
  • This induction is dependent on the regulatory protein , FNR , a factor essential for the transcription of a number of genes expressed during anaerobic growth ( Cole and Ward , 1973 ; Lambden and Guest , 1976 ; Griffiths and Cole , 1987 ) . [2845227]
  • FNR is selectively active as a transcription factor under anaerobic growth conditions , where it has been shown to control the transcription of hundreds of genes , many of which are necessary for adaptation to O2-limiting growth conditions ( 10 , 16 , 25 , 46 ) . [17293415]
  • FNR activates transcription of many genes in response to anaerobic conditions . [16417494]
  • FNR acts as a dual transcription regulator that activates certain genes required for anaerobic growth and represses many genes required for aerobic growth [ 22 ] . [22152010]
  • FNR activates transcription of a number of genes coding for enzymes required under anaerobic growth conditions and represses transcription of some genes for aerobic functions ( 11 , 20 ) . [12923108]
  • Other factors , such as ArcAB ( regulator of anaerobic and aerobic metabolism inhibiting the Krebs-cycle , the electron-transport-chain and PDH activity in anaerobic conditions ) , activate the PFL enzyme ( De Graef et al. , 1999 ) , which is also regulated by FNR . [14595781]
  • Thus , moe operon expression is modulated at three levels : ( 1 ) an aerobic low level , ( 2 ) an anaerobic intermediate level controlled by ArcA-P and FNR ( supporting FHL and DMSO reductase ) , and ( 3 ) by ArcA-phosphate and NarL-phosphate , which , during nitrate respiration , control the highest level of moe operon expression . [11357510]

  • The reduced uptake rates in an fnr background and under aerobic conditions suggest that the synthesis is under ( direct or indirect ) transcriptional-control of FNR , the transcriptional regulator of anaerobic respiratoxy genes ( reviewed in references 25 and 29 ) . [1512189]
  • The transcriptional-control of anaerobic-respiration by the transcriptional regulator FNR takes place in a completely different mode . [1854188]
  • Therefore it appears that FNR is the specific regulator of anaerobic-respiration and related functions . [1854188]
  • FNR is the regulator of genes required for anaerobic-respiration and related pathways . [9230919]
  • Remarkably , anaerobic control is mediated neither by FNR , the general anaerobic regulator , nor by ArcA , another anaerobic global regulator ( luchi and Lin , 1988 ; Pascal et aL , 1984 ) . [8596446]
  • TorC autoregulation is different from tor anaerobic control The torCAD operon is fully induced in anaerobiosis but , in contrast to all other known anaerobic respiratory systems , this control is mediated neither by FNR , a pleiotropic anae-robic regulator , nor by ArcA , a response regulator involved in redox control of numerous genes ( Simon et al. , 1994 ) . [10411745]
  • The genes for fumarate respiration and related enzymes ( dcuB , frdABCD , fumB , ttdAB , and ttdT ) are subject to anaerobic induction by the oxygen sensor FNR and to nitrate repression by the NarX-NarL two-component system ( 15 , 16 , 37 , 46 ) . [20233924]

  • enome-Wide Expression Analysis Indicates that FNR G of Escherichia coli K-12 Regulates a Large Number of Genes of Unknown Function † Yisheng Kang ,1 K. Derek Weber ,2 Yu Qiu ,1 Patricia J. Kiley ,2 and Frederick R. Blattner1 * Department of Genetics1 and Department of Biomolecular Chemistry ,2 University of Wisconsin , Madison , Wisconsin Received 10 June 2004/Accepted 11 October 2004 The major regulator controlling the physiological switch between aerobic and anaerobic growth conditions in Escherichia coli is the DNA binding protein FNR . [15659690]
  • Accepted 3 June 2010 INTRODUCTION The Escherichia coli FNR ( regulator of fumarate and nitrate reduction ) protein is an oxygen-responsive global transcription factor ( Constantinidou et al. , 2006 ; Green et al. , 2009 ; Green & Paget , 2004 ; Kang et al. , 2005 ; Partridge et al. , 2006 , 2007b ; Salmon et al. , 2003 ; Unden et al. , 2002 ) . [20522491]
  • The E.coli FNR protein ( regulator of fumarate and nitrate reduction ) is the global transcription factor that manages the distribution of RNA polymerase in response to oxygen starvation . [17164287]
  • The FNR transcription factor of E. col ~ an oxygen sensor In response to lowered oxygen tension , the metabolism of E. coli switches from use of oxygen to use of alternative terminal electron acceptors such as fumarate and nitrate , a change that requires the simultaneous transcriptional activation of over 50 genes of anaerobic metabolism . [8871401]
  • Hence , absence of oxygen triggers the activity of FNR ( fumarate and nitrate reduction regulator ) , a well-characterized transcription factor that is the master regulator of E. coli adaptation to growth in anaerobic conditions [ 4 ] . [20533909]
  • The transcription factor FNR , the regulator of fumarate and nitrate reduction , regulates major changes as Escherichia coli adapts from aerobic to anaerobic growth . [16377617]
  • The global transcription factor FNR controls the adaptation of Escherichia coli to growth under anaerobic conditions ( 16 ) . [19251855]
  • Genes of Global Regulators of Aerobic/Anaerobic Metabolism Genes coding for global regulators of aerobic ( ArcAB ) and anaerobic ( FNR ) metabolism in E. coli were also tested and their transcription levels are shown in Figure 8 . [16187334]
  • FNR is known to induce the transcription of the E. coli nrfABCDEFG operon during anaerobic cell-growth [ 22 ] , and to negatively regulate the transcription of E. coli hmp [ 7 ] . [12586421]
  • FNR , a transcription factor known to positively regulate a flavohemoglobin homolog in the bacterium Vitreoscilla as well as many denitrification enzymes in other species , actually represses anaerobic expression of the E. coli hmp ( 14 , 16 , 17 ) . [9852058]
  • A primary role for FNR is to coordinate carbon and energy metabolism during growth under anaerobic conditions . [12754220]
  • In E. coli , the NO-induction of the hmpA gene was reported to be dependent on MetR , a transcriptional regulator of the methionine biosynthetic pathway , under aerobic conditions ( 23 ) and on FNR , an oxygen-responsive regulator , under anaerobic conditions ( 24 ) . [14718666]
  • Induction was dependent on the transcriptional regulator ArcA , with a second transcriptional regulator , FNR , playing a negative role speciﬁcally under anaerobic conditions ( S. Darie and R. P. Gunsalus , J. Bacteriol . [8550494]
  • Second , characterization of regulatory mutations that caused moderate anaerobic derepression of sodA : : lacZ protein fusions identified FNR as an additional negative regulator of sodA expression that increases the downregulation further ( 6-fold ) ( 56 , 57 ) . [20075074]
  • These results suggest that the FNR protein acts as a negative regulator of moe operon in controlling the basal level of expression . [11357510]
  • We also report the identification of a subset of these genes that are regulated by a global regulatory protein for anaerobic metabolism , FNR . [12754220]
  • In contrast , the expression of fumB resembles that of the fumarate reductase operon and some other ` anaerobic ' genes in being depressed anaerobically by a mechanism that involves FNR , the CRP-like anaerobic transcriptional activator protein . [3282546]
  • On the other hand , converting this putative FNR protein binding site into the FNR protein binding site core consensus resulted in elevated anaerobic induction of thefdn operon and also caused weak aerobic expression . [1629153]
  • Under anaerobic conditions FNR is a dimeric iron-sulfur protein that binds at specific DNA sequences to activate the expression of `` anaerobic genes '' and to repress the expression of `` aerobic genes '' ( 7 , 8 , 13 ) . [21252224]
  • To incorporate a role for IscR , we would suggest that for the napF promoter , anaerobic activation of the downstream promoter ( s ) via FNR , a bona ﬁde anaerobic global regulator , and NarP , a nitrate-dependent activator ( Darwin et al. , 1998 ; Stewart et al. , 2003 ) , masks detection of IscR-dependent changes in expression from the upstream promoter ( Fig. 4C ) . [16677314]
  • This suggests that during anaerobic growth in liquid cultures in the absence of glucose , FNR is the major regulator of hlyE expression , and that CRP-mediated hlyE expression requires the presence of H-NS . [14996792]
  • The fnr mutant , lacking the O2-responsive regulator FNR , was completely devoid of dcuC9-9lacZ expression during aerobic and anaerobic growth . [10368146]
  • We supposed that FNR was responsible for the effect in the anaerobic condition , because FNR was the global transcriptional regulator that controlled gene-expression in response to the transition between aerobic and anaerobic growth ( Green et al. , 2001 ) . [17618229]
  • Results FNR is an NO sensor The starting point for this work was the observation that the oxygen-responsive global transcription factor FNR represses expression of the NO-detoxifying protein Hmp during anaerobic growth ( Poole et al. , 1996 ) . [12093725]
  • NarL controls the expression of many proteins involved in anaerobic-respiration and , at most of its known promoter targets , it co-regulates transcription together with another global transcription factor , protein FNR , the ` master ' regulator of anaerobic adaptation [ 2,8 -- 10 ] . [19245365]
  • Finally , FNR has been shown to have an indirect effect on anaerobic induction of tdc expression , possibly by controlling levels of an important metabolite ( Chattopadhyay et al. , 1997 ) . [11251844]
  • The likely explanation for this is that most of the genes controlled by these promoters encode products that play a role in anaerobic-respiration of nitrate and nitrite , and thus their expression is fully induced only in both the absence of oxygen ( signalled via FNR ) and the presence of nitrate or nitrite ( signalled by NarL ) [ 4,29,30 ] . [19245365]
  • Our studies have focused on understanding the role of FNR in activating expression of the genes encoding the anaerobic terminal reductases for nitrate , narGHJI ( Stewart and Rabin , 1995 ) , and dimethyl sulphoxide , dmsABC ( Cotter and Gunsalus , 1989 ) . [11115116]
  • A primary role for FNR is to coordinate carbon and energy metabolism under anaerobic growth conditions , and results from global gene-expression profiling revealed that a very large number of genes ( 200 operons ) directly or indirectly are controlled by FNR ( 32 -- 34 ) . [20075074]
  • To identify the global changes and adjustments of gene-expression patterns that facilitate a transition from aerobic to anaerobic growth conditions , and to determine the effects of genotype on these gene-expression patterns , we analyzed E. coli gene-expression profiles obtained from cells cultured under aerobic or anaerobic growth conditions ( O2 or O2 ) and under anaerobic growth conditions in the presence or absence of the global regulatory protein for anaerobic metabolism , FNR ( O2 , FNR or O2 , FNR ) . [12754220]
  • To identify the genes controlled by FNR , we analyzed gene-expression profiles of cells cultured under anaerobic growth conditions in the presence or absence of FNR ( O , 2 FNR or O , FNR ) in otherwise isogenic strains . [12754220]
  • To identify genes controlled by FNR , we used Affymetrix Antisense GeneChips to compare global gene-expression proﬁles from isogenic MG1655 wild-type and fnr strains grown in glucose minimal media under aerobic or anaerobic conditions . [15659690]
  • The lpd ( lpdA ) gene , encoding lipoamide dehydrogenase , a member of the phdR-aceEF-lpdA operon ( Fig. 6 ) , shows a 4.8-fold decrease in expression when grown under anaerobic conditions and a 11.4-fold increase in the FNR deletion strain . [12754220]
  • FnrS is involved in gene regulation after the shift from aerobic to anaerobic conditions , and its expression is activated by the transcription factors FNR and ArcA ( 20 , 21 ) . [23980183]
  • The transcription factor FNR ( for fumarate and nitrate reduction ) plays a major role in altering gene-expression between aerobic and anaerobic conditions to facilitate such changes in energy metabolism . [9990723]
  • Thefnr gene product , FNR , activates the anaerobic expression of nitrate reductase ( 23 ) , dimethyl sulfoxide reductase ( 6 ) , and fumarate reductase ( 11 ) . [8432709]
  • During anaerobic growth the fumarate and nitrate reduction regulator ( FNR ) was important for ClyA expression , and the clyA gene could be activated by overexpression of FNR . [11053378]
  • Surnrnary In enteric bacteria , the expression of rnany genes encoding various anaerobic electron-transfer functions is controlled by FNR , the product of the auto-regulated fnrgene . [2677602]
  • Mean gene-expression data ( fold change ) , acquired from the WT and ECOM4LA strains grown in triplicate , for all genes that are known to be regulated by the anaerobic regulator FNR or ArcA according to RegulonDB were compared to the reported function of the regulator ( activator or repressor ) . [20709841]

  • Physiological role of FNR : target genes FNR , originally identified as the transcriptional regulator of anaerobic-respiration in E. coli ( Lambden and Guest 1976 ; Newman and Cole 1978 ; Chippaux et al. 1978 ) , has now been recognized as a general regulator of anaerobic metabolism that affects many genes of diverse functions ( Table 2 ) . [8588737]
  • One mechanism involves the transcriptional activator and repressor FNR , the major role of which is to regulate the expression of genes involved in anaerobic-respiration and pyruvate-metabolism ( Spiro & Guest 1991 ) . [7747934]
  • In E. coli , the expressions of the genes encoding the enzymes catalyzing the fermentation and respiration are under the control of some global regulators such as FNR and ArcA/B system . [15781419]
  • E. coli has two distinct regulators that control expression of the many genes involved in the aerobic-anaerobic shift : the ArcB/ArcA two-component system and FNR . [20709841]
  • Repression of in vitro transcription of the Escherichia coli fnr and narX genes by R protein The expression of respiratory genes in E. coli is controlled by two trandscriptional regulatory systems : one is the ArcB/A system for aerobic genes [ l ] ; and the other is the FNR system for anaerobic genes [ 2 ] . [8119409]
  • Introduction The expression of genes required for anaerobic growth of Escherichia coli is tightly controlled , and many such genes are reguiated by the FNR protein , a transcription factor that is activated by the absence of oxygen in the medium ( reviewed by Spiro and Guest , 1990 ) . [8437517]
  • Introduction In Escherichia coli , the expression of many genes required for anaerobic-respiration is controlled by the FNR protein , an anaerobically triggered transcription activator ( reviewed by Guest et al. , 1996 ) . [10972841]

  • Department of Microbiology and Molecular Genetics , and the Molecular Biology Institute , 1602 Molecular Sciences Building , University of California , Los Angeles , CA 90095 The Escherichia colifnr gene product , FNR , is a global transcriptional regulator that under anaerobic conditions , activates the expression of a number of anaerobic electron transport-related genes , including nitrate reductase ( narGHJI ) , fumarate reductase ( frdABCD ) , trimethylamine-N-oxide/dimethyl sulfoxide reductase ( dmsABC ) , nitrite reductase ( nirB ) , nitrite export ( narK ) , and formate dehydrogenase ( fdnGHI ) ( 1 ) .   • Introduction In Escherichia coli , the transcription factor FNR facilitates adaptation to anaerobic growth conditions by regulating the expression of gene products that are involved in anaerobic energy metabolism ( Spiro and Guest , 1990 ) . [11115116]
  • FNR primarily functions to regulate anaerobic metabolism in E. coli and other bacteria by co-ordinating changes in gene-expression that optimize growth potential in different niches . [20522491]
  • The ansB gene encodes the anaerobic asparaginase I1 of E. and coli requires FNR and anaerobic growth with 17 amino acids for maximum expression ( Jennings & Beacham , 1993 ; Cedar & Schwartz , 1968 ) . [9308170]

[1854188]
  • The Escherichia coli yhjA gene , encoding a predicted cytochrome c peroxidase , is regulated by FNR and OxyR . [20522491]
  • introduction The expression of many of the gene products needed for anaerobic growth of Escherichia coli is tightly regulated and dependent on the FNR protein , a transcription factor Received 4 January , 1994 ; revised 31 May , 1994 ; accepted 2 June , 1994 . [7854119]

  • 35 , No. 1 269 -- 278 doi :10.1093 / nar/gkl1023 Transcription factor distribution in Escherichia coli : studies with FNR protein David C. Grainger * , Hirofumi Aiba , Douglas Hurd , Douglas F. Browning and 1 2 Stephen J. W. Busby School of Biosciences , University of Birmingham , Edgbaston , Birmingham B15 2TT , UK , Laboratory of 1 Molecular Microbiology , School of Agriculture , Nagoya University , Chikusa-ku , Nagoya 464-8601 , Japan and 2 Oxford Gene Technology , Begbroke Science Park , Sandy Lane , Yarnton , Oxford OX5 1PF , UK Received August 25 , 2006 ; Revised November 8 , 2006 ; Accepted November 14 , 2006 ABSTRACT Using chromatin immunoprecipitation ( ChIP ) and high-density microarrays , we have measured the distribution of the global transcription regulator protein , FNR , across the entire Escherichia coli chromosome in exponentially growing cells . [17164287]
  • Contents lists available at SciVerse ScienceDirect Biochemical and Biophysical Research Communications journal homepage : www.elsevier.com/locate/ybbrc Covalently linking the Escherichia coli global anaerobic regulator FNR in tandem allows it to function as an oxygen stable dimer Yue Shan a , Qing Pan a , Junyan Liu a , Feijuang Huang b , Hongzhe Sun b , Kunihiko Nishino c , Aixin Yan a , ⇑ a School of Biological Sciences , The University of Hong Kong , Hong Kong , China b Department of Chemistry , The University of Hong Kong , Hong Kong , China c Institute of Scientiﬁc and Industrial Research , Osaka University , Osaka 567-0047 , Japan a r t i c l e i n f o a b s t r a c t The anaerobic global regulator FNR from Escherichia coli is a [ 4Fe -- 4S ] 2 + cluster containing , O2 labile dimer that plays an important role in adapting the bacterium to its anaerobic lifestyle .   • Both CRP and FNR are 50-kDa homodimers that bind related inverted-repeats with a TGANNNNNNTCA core motif ( 12 ) . [14996792]
  • Conserved positions in the inveriedrepeat thought to be recognizedby FNR are shown in bold face and the probable ' -10 ' sequences recognized by RNA polymeraseare overlined . [2677602]
